TITLE: Comparison of Hermia in A Midsummer Night's Dream and Jessica in TheMerchant of Venice
HUMAN ESSAY:
Hermia and Jessica

At first glance, Hermia of Midsummer Night's Dream and Jessica of Merchant of Venice appear to be similar characters. Both women run away from homes characterized by commanding fathers and absent mothers in order to marry their lovers. Patriarchy is blatantly defied in both situations, but Hermia and Jessica have very different relationships with their fathers and defy them to varying degrees. If the term defy is used in its most malignant context, it means, to renounce faith, allegiance, or affiance to (any one); to declare hostilities or war against (Oxford English Dictionary). By this definition, and assuming that more rebellion equals more success, Jessica is more successful in defying her father. This can be seen through Jessica's hostile relationship with her father, her renunciation of Judaism, and her cruel robbery of Shylock that includes trading his ring for a monkey.

Jessica has a negative relationship with her father, Shylock, which Shakespeare never fully explains. In her second line of the play she declares, Our house is hell (II.iii.2, Merchant). Before she even mentions Lorenzo, Jessica speaks of her father with distain. She goes on to say, Alack, what a heinous sin is it in me/ To be ashamed to be my father's child! But though I am a daughter to his blood,/ I am not to his manners (II.iii.16-19, Merchant). Jessica openly states that she is ashamed to be Shylock's daughter, and though she admits that her feelings are sinful, she does not show any signs of guilt or remorse. She takes comfort that she is not like her father, but she never elaborates on what she finds distasteful in his character. A fair assumption may be that she is unhappy about being born a Jew and that she resents her father for passing on Judaism to her. Jessica loves a Christian man and plans to convert so she can marry him: I shall end this strife,/ Become a Christian and thy loving wife (II.iii.20-21, Merchant). One definition of defy is to renounce faith [to], which Jessica does both in terms of faith as loyalty to her father, as well as faith in a religious sense. Hermia, on the other hand, does not insult her father Egeus's character or oppose him beyond his choice for her husband. His favor for Demetrius appears arbitrary and he lacks a valid argument against Lysander's character, family, or wealth. This portrays Hermia's defiance as less severe and more sympathetic than Jessica's.

In the first scene of A Midsummer Night's Dream, Hermia pleads with her father to let her marry Lysander instead of Demetrius. She boldly tells the duke, I would my father look'd but with my eyes (I.i.56, Midsummer). She would rather have her father's blessing than rebel against him, but she feels entitled to a choice in which man she marries. Conversely, Jessica never gives her father the chance to disapprove of her lover. She prepares to run away with Lorenzo in secret, commanding Launcelot to, give him this letter, do it secretly… I would not have my father/ See me in talk with thee (II.iii.7-9, Merchant). Both women speak of their father's sight, but with opposite hopes. Hermia wishes her father would relent and see from her perspective, while Jessica hopes her father remains blind to her scheme to run away. Hermia is ultimately unsuccessful at changing her father's view as the last thing Egeus says in the play is: I beg the law, the law, upon his head. /They would have stol'n away… Demetrius, Thereby to have defeated you and me:/ You of your wife, and me of my consent (IV.i.155-158, Midsummer). Egeus never gives his consent for Hermia and Lysander to marry; it is Theseus who overrules Egeus and gives the lovers his blessing. Jessica, however, is successful at running away with Lorenzo without Shylock discerning her plan.

Ironically, Shylock asks Jessica to take care of his house while he is away, Jessica, my girl,/ Look to my house… Lock up my doors… Let not the sound of fopp'ry enter/ My sober house (II.v.15-36, Merchant). Not only does Jessica disregard her father's orders (as she does earlier when he tries to call her) but she robs the house of its treasures, including a casket of jewels and Shylock's wedding ring. When Tubal informs him that the ring was traded for a monkey, Shylock bursts into hysterics: Out upon her! Thou torturest me, Tubal. It was my turkis, I had it of Leah when I was a bachelor. I would not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys (III.i.120-124, Merchant). Shylock is sympathetic here, especially as the importance of wedding rings becomes integral in Act V when Portia and Nerissa berate their husbands for giving their rings away. Jessica's careless dispense of the ring goes beyond defiant to cruel and vindictive. Hermia, on the other hand, steals only herself from her father's house. She never inflicts the kind of pain on Egeus that Jessica inflicts on Shylock.

If success in defying one's father is measured by the degree of hostility, Jessica certainly achieves more success than Hermia. However, at the end of the plays, Jessica's marriage seems doomed and Hermia's appears successful. When Hermia and Lysander enter after the wedding ceremony, Theseus says, Here come the lovers, full of joy and mirth (V.i.27, Midsummer). Little else is said about the couple, but there is no reason to think they will be unhappy. Conversely, the scene between Jessica and Lorenzo at the end of The Merchant of Venice does not bode well for their future. First, they compare themselves to famous lovers whose stories end unhappily. Then Jessica says, Did young Lorenzo swear he lov'd her well,/ Stealing her soul with many vows of faith,/ And ne'er a true one (V.i.17-19, Merchant) and Lorenzo replies, Did pretty Jessica (like a little shrow)/ Slander her love… (V.i.21-22, Merchant). This may hide in the guise of playful romantic banter, but Jessica's accusation of false vows, and Lorenzo calling his wife a shrow (meaning shrew) has a serious undertone. Later in the scene the lovers seem to be disconnected and lacking communication. The musicians enter and Jessica says: I am never merry when I hear sweet music (V.i.69, Merchant). Lorenzo replies in a long speech that ends with: The man that hath no music in himself,/ Nor is not moved with concord of sweet sounds,/ is fit for treason, stratagems, and spoils… Let no such man be trusted (V.i.83-88, Merchant). The man Lorenzo speaks of is not literally male, but mankind in an all encompassing sense. He does not seem to notice that this grave accusation of treason and untrustworthiness applies to his new wife, who has just said she is unmoved by music. The fact that Jessica's last line of the play includes I am never merry gives weight to the feeling that the lovers are not going to live happily ever after. It gives the reader cause to question how much Jessica and Lorenzo loved each other in the first place. Jessica may have seen Lorenzo as an opportunity to escape her father and convert to Christianity. Running away and renouncing her faith are never portrayed as a sacrifice or risk for Jessica. Rather, she eagerly betrays her father in a manner that could be construed as careless and hasty.

At the end of The Merchant of Venice Jessica reaps the consequences of betraying her father and her faith, as Portia and the other Christians are unwelcoming. This outsider status could possibly symbolize a future exclusion from Heaven for Jessica. After her escape, Shylock declares, She is damned for it (III.i.31, Merchant), meaning that he believes Jessica is going to Hell for running away from him and becoming a Christian. Lancelot also thinks Jessica will be barred from Heaven as he tells her, the sins of the father are to be laid upon the children… for truly I think you are damn'd (III.v.1-6, Merchant). Lancelot does not blame Jessica's sins for her damnation, but rather her father's. However, it remains ambiguous whether Shylock was serious about taking a pound of Antonio's flesh until he learned of Jessica's flight. Her actions were the last straw for him, and after declaring his daughter damned, he gives his famous speech: To bait a fish withal- if it will feed nothing else, it will feed my revenge… Hath not a Jew eyes? (III.i.53-59). Therefore, it's possible that if Jessica had not defied her father, he may have had a change of heart, consequently, alleviating sin from herself. This may be farfetched, but at the end of the play, Jessica remains an outsider. Despite her efforts, she is more like her father than ever, as they are both Christian converts that risk never being accepted by Jews, Christians, and possibly even God. When examined in this light, Jessica's defiance against Shylock has gone terribly wrong.

After close inspection of Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream and A Merchant of Venice it becomes clear that both Jessica and Hermia are successful at defying their fathers in different ways. If successful defiance is measured by greater rebellion and cruelty, Jessica certainly wins. However, if the daughter's happiness at the end of each play is a better measure for successful defiance, then Hermia's less severe approach achieves more. Ultimately, if success is to be associated with happiness and not the degree of defiance, one must conclude that less is more.

Comparison of Hermia in A Midsummer Night’s Dream and Jessica in The Merchant of Venice

The works of William Shakespeare are populated with characters whose struggles, desires, and choices reveal the complexities of early modern society and human nature. Among these figures, Hermia in A Midsummer Night’s Dream and Jessica in The Merchant of Venice stand out as young women whose narratives explore love, autonomy, obedience, and identity in markedly different but thematically related ways. Both characters challenge the social and familial structures that confine them, yet the consequences of their choices and the thematic frameworks of their respective plays produce distinctive portraits of female agency. By examining the cultural contexts of each play, the motivations and actions of Hermia and Jessica, and the ways Shakespeare constructs their relationships with family, love, and personal identity, one can see how these characters simultaneously resist and reflect the gendered constraints of their worlds. Though they appear in comedies, their stories are embedded within the serious issues of authority, religious identity, and social hierarchy. Through them, Shakespeare presents nuanced explorations of choice and consequence in a patriarchal society.

Social and Familial Constraints

Hermia and Jessica are introduced in situations defined by paternal authority. Hermia faces her father Egeus’s demand that she marry Demetrius, despite her love for Lysander. This conflict is stated directly when Egeus implores Theseus to enforce Athenian law, declaring Hermia must “consent to marry with Demetrius” or face death or lifelong chastity (Shakespeare, A Midsummer Night’s Dream, 1.1). Hermia’s very existence becomes subject to legal judgment, reflecting a society in which daughters are expected to obey fathers without question. The public nature of the dispute—brought before Duke Theseus—exposes Hermia’s lack of control over her own marriage and underscores the patriarchal power that defines her world. In contrast, Jessica’s conflict is not publicly litigated, yet it is equally fraught. As the daughter of Shylock, she is confined within a home that she describes as a “hell,” expressing emotional and spiritual suffocation (Shakespeare, The Merchant of Venice, 2.3). Although Shylock’s authority is not backed by explicit legal threats like those faced by Hermia, his rigid control, particularly in matters of religion and social connection, shapes Jessica’s desire to escape. The private, domestic nature of her confinement underscores a different dimension of patriarchal authority: not one upheld by state law but by religious and cultural boundaries.

Despite the different forms of paternal control, both characters respond with defiance. However, Hermia’s disobedience emerges within a space where female agency is at least conversationally permitted, if not societally validated. She boldly states her intention to refuse Demetrius and shows unwavering loyalty to Lysander, asserting she “will not” marry the unwanted suitor even in Theseus’s presence (1.1). Jessica’s disobedience, though equally resolute, must occur covertly. She plots her escape in secrecy, steals from her father, and elopes with Lorenzo, a Christian. Her rebellion therefore entails not only marital choice but religious conversion and cultural betrayal. In both cases, the daughters’ resistance challenges paternal authority, yet the stakes of Jessica’s choice extend far beyond marriage to encompass identity transformation and the abandonment of her heritage.

Romantic Relationships and the Assertion of Choice

Hermia’s relationship with Lysander is portrayed as mutually affectionate, poetic, and idealized. Their love appears genuine and reciprocal from the outset, and their elopement plan, while dangerous, seems driven by romantic sincerity rather than opportunism. Lysander’s devotion to Hermia is confirmed repeatedly, even though supernatural interference threatens to distort his affections later in the play. Hermia’s insistence on maintaining boundaries during their journey into the forest—such as when she resists sharing a bed with Lysander—reinforces her integrity and personal strength (2.2). Her love is steadfast, moralized, and consistent with the play’s themes of youthful romantic idealism.

Jessica’s relationship with Lorenzo, in contrast, has long been scrutinized by readers and scholars for its ambiguity and possible opportunism. Though she declares her love and expresses willingness to abandon her father’s house, Jessica’s motivations are complex. Her conversion to Christianity and adoption into Lorenzo’s social circle appear to offer her both emotional and social liberation. However, her elopement is also intertwined with material concerns, as she takes her father’s wealth and spends it lavishly after escaping, including on a ring prized by Shylock (3.1). Lorenzo’s language about Jessica is affectionate, yet he often speaks of her in terms of possession, as when he refers to her as “a gentle and no Jew” after her conversion (2.4). Unlike Hermia’s romance, which is built on emotional equality, Jessica’s relationship suggests uneven power dynamics and complexities of assimilation. Her willingness to change her religion raises questions about whether love alone motivates her or whether her desire for freedom—economic, social, and spiritual—drives her choices.

Hermia’s assertion of choice ultimately reinforces her sense of self. Despite the chaotic interference of the fairies, she remains consistent in her identity and devotion. Jessica, by contrast, undergoes a transformation that raises questions about the cost of her autonomy. While she chooses freedom over obedience, the nature of that freedom—gained by severing her ties to her father and heritage—introduces a sense of loss absent from Hermia’s narrative. Thus, while both characters assert romantic agency, the consequences and moral valences of their choices differ sharply.

Identity, Freedom, and Transformation

A key point of comparison between Hermia and Jessica lies in how Shakespeare uses their characters to explore identity. Hermia’s conflict does not fundamentally alter her sense of self. Though she faces external pressures and is subject to magical manipulation, the core of her identity remains stable. She is assertive, articulate, morally grounded, and loyal. Even when Lysander temporarily rejects her due to the enchantment, Hermia persists in her belief in their relationship and her own worth. After the enchantment is resolved, she emerges unchanged, reaffirmed in her love and autonomy. Her identity is threatened externally but never internally ruptured.

Jessica’s identity is radically transformed. Her elopement requires adopting a Christian identity, which in early modern England signified far more than a personal spiritual choice. It represented social belonging, political loyalty, and cultural assimilation. By converting, Jessica symbolically rejects her Jewish heritage and embraces the dominant culture—an action that complicates her identity rather than confirming it. Her decisions raise questions about belonging and selfhood that Hermia never faces. While Hermia’s struggle is framed as a conflict between personal desire and external control, Jessica’s is a conflict between inherited identity and chosen identity. Even after her escape, the play leaves lingering questions about her feelings toward her father and her new community. When she spends Shylock’s turquoise ring “for a monkey,” a choice Lorenzo mentions lightly, the action suggests a certain carelessness toward her past (3.1). Yet the audience receives no clear emotional resolution from Jessica herself. Her silence throughout much of the latter half of the play leaves her transformation feeling incomplete and uneasy.

Thematic Contexts and Their Influence on Characterization

Each character’s narrative operates within the thematic framework of her respective play, shaping how Shakespeare constructs and resolves her story. In A Midsummer Night’s Dream, issues of love, illusion, and transformation are comedic and whimsical. The forest setting functions as a space of possibility, chaos, and eventual harmony. Hermia’s conflict, though serious in the social context of the time, is treated comedically through the magical interventions of the fairies. Ultimately, the resolution aligns with the genre’s expectation of restored order and happy unions. Theseus overrules Egeus and permits Hermia’s marriage to Lysander, demonstrating the play’s emphasis on reconciliation and romantic fulfillment (4.1). Hermia’s story supports the play’s overarching message about the irrationality of love and the ability of harmony to emerge from disorder.

The Merchant of Venice, however, is far more thematically ambivalent. Issues of prejudice, justice, mercy, and religious conflict permeate the play. Jessica’s narrative intersects with these themes intimately, especially the conflict between Christian and Jewish communities. Her escape serves as both a romantic plot and a cultural allegory, reinforcing Christian triumph and Jewish isolation as presented in the play’s worldview. Because the play oscillates between comedic and tragic elements, Jessica’s story lacks the comedic neatness of Hermia’s resolution. Instead, her final situation—living among Christians, connected to Shylock’s financial ruin, and silent about her own inner life—reflects the play’s unresolved tensions. Unlike Hermia, Jessica does not receive a clear narrative affirmation of her choices; instead, her transformation remains an unsettling reminder of the cultural pressures that define her world.

Female Agency and Shakespeare’s Commentary on Patriarchy

Hermia and Jessica both exercise agency, but the nature of that agency reveals different dimensions of Shakespeare’s critique of patriarchal society. Hermia’s defiance is valorized. She speaks boldly, challenges both her father and Duke Theseus, and insists upon autonomy in her romantic life. Shakespeare frames her resistance sympathetically, emphasizing her moral conviction and emotional sincerity. Her triumphant conclusion affirms her agency and suggests a hopeful vision of women’s autonomy within the bounds of comedy.

Jessica’s agency, while present, is fraught with moral and cultural implications. Her decision to abandon her father and her religion raises ethical questions that Shakespeare does not fully address. Though early audiences may have viewed Jessica’s conversion positively, modern readers recognize the complexities of her situation. Her agency is intertwined with assimilation into a dominant culture that marginalizes her father and community. Unlike Hermia, whose assertion of freedom is celebrated without lasting conflict, Jessica attains freedom at the cost of severing ties to her origins. Shakespeare thereby presents a more ambivalent exploration of female autonomy—one that reflects the broader social tensions of early modern England, including attitudes toward religious difference and cultural identity.

Conclusion

Hermia and Jessica, though both young women navigating restrictive societies, embody distinct responses to the challenges of love, authority, and identity. Hermia’s story, framed by the comedic and fantastical world of A Midsummer Night’s Dream, portrays a resolute pursuit of romantic and personal autonomy, ultimately affirmed by the play’s restoration of harmony. Jessica’s narrative in The Merchant of Venice, shaped by themes of religious tension and cultural displacement, reflects a more complex and ambiguous form of agency. Her escape grants her freedom but at the cost of profound personal transformation and unresolved ethical questions. Together, Hermia and Jessica reveal Shakespeare’s nuanced engagement with the constraints placed upon women in his society. Through them, Shakespeare explores how love can both challenge and reinforce patriarchal norms, how identity can be asserted or relinquished, and how personal autonomy is shaped by the cultural forces that surround it. Their stories remain compelling lenses through which to consider the intersections of family, society, and female choice in Shakespeare’s works.

Shakespeare, William. A Midsummer Night’s Dream.

Shakespeare, William. The Merchant of Venice.

The Freedom of One Word

Existentialist philosophy asserts that we live in a broken world (Marcel). An ambiguous world (de Beauvoir). A dislocated world (Merleau-Ponty). A world of indifference. Of absurdity (Camus). One we are thrown into and abandoned in, yet condemned and free (Heidegger and Sartre). It is this philosophy that detonates what superficially appears to be the doctrine of a dark and dismal lifestyle, yet it is quite the opposite. It is a philosophy of freedom, of choice, of letting go of that which is unimportant and accepting a world characterized by irrationality and indifference. Grounded in the freedom of self-invention and power of choice, one is not bound to the simplifications and theoretical definitions of others have determined what being human predicates, but the assertion that individual man defines his own reality and existence.

Often times in literature, an existentialist figure will find himself separated from the world and other people. As a result of feeling isolated or alone, he feels threatened, meaningless, insignificant, but learns to embrace the unresolvable confusion of the human world and resist the all-too-human desire to resolve that confusion by extending himself to whatever appears or can be made to appear safe or familiar. Published in 1952 by Ralph Ellison, the disoriented protagonist of Invisible Man fits this description by facing a confusing world in which he cannot fit into. Wherever Ellison's unnamed Negro character travels in the novel, he is weakened and left rootless by people who did either entirely disregard his inner character or envisage and use him as a symbol. In the 581-page novel, the narrator spends much of it shifting his personality like the colors on that of a chameleon, as each time he throws off that mask, he finds himself trapped inside another stereotype or disguise. In Ellison's existential bildungsroman, it is only until he realizes the absurdity and irrationality of the world that he is able to free himself of the building expectations of the roles he feels he is supposed to play. A close reading of the opening passage and concluding passages demonstrates the existential ontogenesis of Ellison's protagonist as it exhibits his movement from rural innocence to cosmopolitan maturity and disillusionment. With the discovery of one word, he finds himself free, free of the expectations and roles and he creates his own reality, and finally able to establish his identity as the man he wants to be.

Following a wild and disorienting prologue, the narrator begins in the first paragraph with self reflection. He comments, All my life I had been looking for something, and everywhere I turned someone tried to tell me what it was…I was looking for myself and asking everyone except myself questions which I, and only I, could answer (15). Acting as frame for the novel, this narrative gives readers the context for the story of an existential bildungsroman.

Occurring later in the first chapter, the narrator attends a gathering to give his celebrated graduation speech to the significant white men of the community. Expecting a proper, polite, and respectable gathering, the narrator finds the scene of to be the exact opposite. He finds himself hurled into a group of other Negro boys, forced watch a beautiful, stark naked woman dance, and then fight in a humiliating battle royal. Serving no purpose other than vulgar entertainment for the prominent white men of the town, the battle royal exists as another occasion in the novel where white men take advantage of the narrator's passivity and idealistic nature.

In addition to heightening the tension between submission and rebellion, the battle royal can be seen as a contrast of the narrator's personality, between his youth and later developed self. Later in the novel at the occurrence of his existential revelation, he has a specific understanding and diction to describe the procession of chaotic ongoing events surrounding him. But, during the battle royal, he endures the same injustice, the same randomness, the same irrationality and problems of agency, yet he equivocally describes it. He claims he had some misgivings over the battle royal (17), feels guilt and fear (19) and blind terror (21). Despite the loss of his dignity (I had no dignity (22) in the mad (20) anarchy (21) of the situation, the narrator continues to fight automatically (24). He obediently follows and does not question his orders. There was nothing to do but what we were told, he claims (21). A fundamental cornerstone in existentialism is the belief in a choice – there is always a choice. With the narrator indicating he had none, Ellison highlights his immaturity and inability to command his own life as lives in the shadows of others.

In stark contrast of his thoughts and self at the end of the novel, Ellison willfully places this scene as the opening chapter. The absolute absurdity and irrationality of this commencing incident is no mistake. Ellison purposely introduces his narrator in a light of inferiority and literal and metaphorical blindness to show the development of his protagonist into a confident existentialist figure. Ellison extends his naïveté through the symbol of the blindfold. The blindfold parallels the narrator's metaphorical blindness in that he cannot see through the mendacious masks of the white men's benevolence. Like the blindfold, the speech he gives also plays with another theme of the book. His memorized oratory parallels the narrator playing the game as he participates in a sort of performance, a masquerade of acting and playing the part of a humble Negro boy. Contributing to the narrator's metaphorical blindness and performance, the sequence of the battle royal contributes to the narrator's initial steps in becoming the man he chooses to become.

Fast forwarding to chapter 23, the narrator realizes his role in the Brotherhood. Furious to finally understand his function was nothing more than to act as a puppet for a corrupt organization, the narrator begins a deep process of self reflection. He comments,

And now all past humiliations became precious parts of my experience, and for the first time…I began to accept my past…I saw that [images of past humiliations] were more than separate experiences. They were me; they defined me. I was my experiences and my experiences were me(507-8).

This passage marks the narrator's commencing conscious process of self-invention as he begins to flirt with existential philosophy in his building of his identity. It is further developed in chapter 25 while under attack by Ras's mob. This is the most crucial moment of the narrator's existential bildungsroman and it begins with Ras threatening his life. 'Hang the lying traitor,' Ras shouted (558). It is at this moment in which the narrator, faced with the very likely prospect of death, begins to see through the eyes of an existentialist. …It seemed unreal. I faced them knowing that a madman in a foreign costume was real and yet unreal, knowing that he wanted my life, that he held me responsible for all the nights and days and all the suffering and for all that which I was incapable of controlling (558). The playing with the words real and unreal plays with the idea of absurdity, of death and existence being absurd, and the world existing as a meaningless scope of irrationality in which he begins to realize his place. In the next paragraph, he repeats the word absurd four times, each time recapitulating the power and force behind that word. He now has a word, a language, to describe the night, Ras's existence, his existence, and the deceptive American masquerading for identity. Unlike his description of the battle royal in which he not once used the word absurd to describe the utterly insane chaos around him – the word absurd means something to now him: it offers him a new direction new and possibilities in life. The repetition of the word absurd furthermore alludes to a fundamental key in existentialism. Ellison crafts his interpretation of the absurd to refer to the objectivity, indifference, and ambiguity the narrator experiences in the world, and simultaneously the possibility of the narrator creating meaning through his actions and interpretations.

His new discovery of the absurd contributes to the narrator's realization for the first time that he has control over his life and the power of choice. [I] recognized the absurdity of the whole night…and I knew that it was better to live out one's own absurdity than to die for that of others, whether for Ras's or Jack's. His existential breakthrough creates the narrator's source of meaning to his life as the narrator's identity. He later comments in the epilogue that my problem was that I always tried to go in everyone's way but my own (573), and following and attempting to fulfill the expectations of others, he found it destructive to his identity and his creation of meaning of his life. The consequent action of throwing the spear back at Ras demonstrates the narrator's commitment to his own identity and his permanent refusal to be subject to others peoples' visions and demands any longer. With this notion, he finally devotes himself totally to an effort to assert his true identity.

The next chapter finds the narrator's story has come full circle, as it both begins and ends with his underground life. Though some critics see his choice to live underground as a cop-out or evasion from his problems, in reading his choice through the philosophy of existentialism, readers find that the importance lies in neither asking if he is evading or snubbing society, but that he has made a choice. Instead of trying to follow the myriad of advice and guidance recommended to him throughout the text, the narrator takes matters into own hands and decides to stay underground to ponder his existence and the meaning he wants his life to have. In his cave, he points out, he does not have the interference of others, and he is open to thinking for himself. At the end of the novel, the narrator affirms his uncertainty in regards to a concrete identity, but determines to venerate his own complexity and duty to society as an individual. In reflecting back to his language and personality in the initial chapter of battle royal then comparing that to the closing episode with Ras, readers witness his movement from rural innocence to maturity and disillusionment in this existential bildungsroman, in which a lone protagonist discovers himself and frees himself of the expectations and roles created by society. Life is to be lived, not controlled, he claims, and humanity is won by continuing to play in the face of defeat (577).

Paper on Invisible Man

Ralph Ellison’s Invisible Man endures as one of the most probing and unsettling examinations of race, power, and selfhood in American literature. First published in 1952, the novel follows an unnamed Black narrator whose journey from a Southern Black college to the streets and political machinery of Harlem becomes a symbolic traversal of the American social landscape. Yet Invisible Man is not simply a record of oppression; it is a philosophical meditation on the ideas that shape individuals and societies—freedom, identity, ideology, and visibility. In exploring these forces, Ellison crafts a narrative that is both explicitly political and deeply personal. The book suggests that to be Black in America is to be rendered invisible by systems that refuse to see one’s complexity, humanity, or individuality. At the same time, Ellison presents a weary but powerful assertion that authenticity can be forged only through a painful unraveling of illusions. This essay argues that Invisible Man demonstrates that genuine personal identity arises only when the protagonist rejects externally imposed narratives—from the college, from white philanthropists, from political organizations like the Brotherhood—and embraces the hard-earned clarity of self-definition.

Identity as Social Construction and Erasure

From the earliest pages of the novel, the narrator’s assertion of invisibility is more than metaphor. As he states, “I am invisible, understand, simply because people refuse to see me” (Ellison 3). His condition stems not from physical absence but from social distortion: others look through him, projecting their assumptions onto him instead of acknowledging his actual self. This invisibility is produced by a society structured around racial hierarchies that reduce Black individuals to symbols or stereotypes. Importantly, the narrator does not initially interpret his invisibility as a social failure; early in the novel he appears eager to fulfill the roles others script for him. His desire to succeed according to socially sanctioned norms reveals that his sense of self is deeply entangled in external validation.

The Battle Royal episode dramatizes this entanglement with brutal clarity. The narrator accepts his invitation to the event because he believes performing well will showcase his intellect and earn him respect. Instead, he is forced into a degrading spectacle of violence and humiliation. Rather than perceiving this as exploitation, he interprets his eventual opportunity to give his speech as evidence that his obedience and diligence will be rewarded. He states, “I felt gratitude... as though I had been given a chance to speak to the world” (Ellison 27). This response reveals how thoroughly he has internalized the notion that the path to success requires submission to white expectations. The scene demonstrates Ellison’s critique of how institutional power—particularly white economic and cultural power—constructs opportunities for Black advancement that are simultaneously demeaning and illusory. The protagonist clings to a false identity shaped by what he imagines powerful white men want him to be.

Such externally imposed identities culminate in the protagonist’s time at the college, where he idolizes Dr. Bledsoe and views the campus as a sanctuary of Black achievement. Yet this idealization masks the college’s deeper reliance on appearances and respectability politics. Bledsoe’s hypocrisy becomes clear when he tells the narrator, “I’s big and black and I say ‘Yes Suh’ as loud as any raggedy black there is, and the white folk trust me” (Ellison 142). Bledsoe’s performance of servility is a calculated tactic for maintaining influence. He manipulates white benefactors but also polices the behavior of other Black people, insisting that they conform to the image he deems acceptable to the white world. By revealing that supposed Black leadership is itself constrained by white expectations, Ellison shows that even Black institutions may perpetuate the narrator’s invisibility. His expulsion from the college marks not only a personal loss but also the collapse of illusions he held about pathways to success within systems designed to keep him subordinate.

The Enticing Trap of Ideology and the Brotherhood

Upon his arrival in Harlem, the narrator continues to search for a framework through which he can understand his place in the world. This search makes him vulnerable to the Brotherhood, a political organization modeled on twentieth-century leftist groups. The Brotherhood promises rationality, progress, equality, and a role for him as a spokesperson for the community. For a time, the narrator is drawn to this promise of ideological clarity. His speech at the eviction protest shows that he possesses charisma and empathy unmediated by dogma. His improvised address focuses on lived experience rather than political doctrine, arguing that the old couple being evicted “belong to us” and should not be discarded (Ellison 278). This speech reveals the narrator’s latent potential for authentic connection with the community.

The Brotherhood, however, quickly redirects his instincts into a rigid ideological framework. Brother Jack insists that the narrator’s personal style must be subordinated to the organization’s theory: “We follow our program, not your emotions” (Ellison 305). The Brotherhood’s insistence on abstraction—the primacy of theory over lived experience—mirrors the narrator’s earlier entrapment by the college. Both institutions offer the illusion of guidance and opportunity while ultimately demanding the suppression of individuality. When the narrator begins to gain influence in Harlem, Jack chastises him for being too charismatic, declaring, “You were not hired to think” (Ellison 371). This assertion makes explicit the Brotherhood’s paternalism: the narrator is valued only insofar as he functions as an instrument of the organization’s goals.

Ellison’s critique of political ideology is particularly incisive here. He is not dismissing collective action or social transformation; rather, he demonstrates how ideology can become another form of blindness. The Brotherhood’s analysis of Harlem’s problems is often detached from the actual needs of the community, and the organization pursues strategic advantage rather than genuine liberation. Its machinations culminate in the abandonment of Harlem at the moment of crisis, leaving the community vulnerable to violence and confusion. In the chaos, the narrator recognizes that the Brotherhood sees him no more clearly than any of the other institutions that have attempted to use him. His invisibility persists, though now he understands it as a function of ideology’s failure to see individuals behind collective categories.

The Symbolic Journey Toward Self-Definition

Throughout the novel, symbols operate as mirrors reflecting the narrator’s evolving understanding of his identity. One of the most striking symbols is the Sambo doll used by Tod Clifton. Before his departure from the Brotherhood, Clifton sells dancing dolls on the street—objects that exaggerate racist caricatures of Blackness. Though this act seems contradictory for someone once devoted to political activism, the symbolism is profound. The Sambo doll represents the way society manipulates Black identity; the strings that make it dance are metaphors for the external forces that dictate Black behavior. When the narrator watches Clifton perform with the doll, he is horrified not only by the degradation but by the recognition that he himself has been similarly controlled. The doll reveals how institutions such as the college and the Brotherhood reduce individuals to predictable movements, stripping them of autonomy.

Another crucial symbol is the briefcase the narrator receives during the Battle Royal. Over time, it becomes a repository for documents, tokens, and remnants of discarded identities: his scholarship letter, his Brotherhood name, his work pamphlets. Each item represents a former version of himself shaped by someone else’s expectations. When he finally burns the contents in the basement during the riot, he symbolically sheds the layers of false identities he has carried. The narrator reflects, “I threw them into the flames and laughed as they burned” (Ellison 567). This act is not a nihilistic rejection of the past; rather, it marks the first moment in which he actively chooses what to discard and what to keep.

The basement itself becomes a paradoxical site of enlightenment. Living underground, surrounded by 1,369 light bulbs, the narrator confronts the contradictions of invisibility. In isolation, he acknowledges how he has been shaped by forces he failed to understand. His retreat underground is not an escape but a reorientation—a space where he can interrogate the assumptions that have governed his life. In this sense, invisibility becomes generative; it allows him to see structures that were previously obscured. The protagonist reflects, “I was never more loved than when I was invisible” (Ellison 580), recognizing that the world’s attempts to define him were never about who he actually was. Instead, they were projections serving the interests of those in power.

Rejecting External Narratives and Embracing Complexity

The novel ultimately suggests that self-discovery requires the narrator to reject not only oppressive social roles but also the desire for simple answers. Invisibility becomes a lens through which he can view the multiplicity of his identity. He concludes that life cannot be organized around ideological certainties, whether supplied by white benefactors, Black leaders, or political organizations. True identity must arise from internal reflection and an embrace of complexity.

The narrator’s reflections in the epilogue articulate this lesson: “Life is to be lived, not controlled; and humanity is won by continuing to play in face of certain defeat” (Ellison 579). This statement encapsulates the paradox of agency within oppressive systems. The narrator recognizes that absolute freedom may be impossible in a society structured by racism, yet he asserts the necessity of striving for authenticity despite constraints. This attitude aligns with existentialist themes present throughout the novel. His journey echoes existentialist arguments that meaning must be created rather than inherited. By choosing to emerge from the basement at the novel’s end, he acts on the understanding that identity is an ongoing process, not a fixed state.

Importantly, Ellison does not suggest that the narrator’s self-understanding is complete. Rather, he acknowledges the ongoing tension between individual identity and social perception. The narrator’s decision to reengage with the world is neither triumphant nor resigned; it is a recognition that invisibility can provide insight but cannot substitute for lived experience. His return signals a willingness to confront the world with clearer eyes, even knowing that society may still refuse to see him. This nuanced ending rejects simplistic narratives of empowerment or redemption, insisting instead on the importance of continual self-examination.

The Novel’s Relevance to Contemporary America

Although Invisible Man was written in the mid-twentieth century, its themes remain urgent in contemporary American discourse. The persistence of racial profiling, systemic inequality, and the commodification of Black culture underscores Ellison’s claim that invisibility is an enduring social condition. Modern movements for racial justice echo the narrator’s desire to be seen as a full and complex human being. Likewise, debates over political representation and ideological purity resonate with Ellison’s critique of organizations that speak for communities without truly listening to them.

The novel also provides insight into the psychological toll of navigating contradictory expectations. Whether in classrooms, boardrooms, or public debates, individuals today continue to grapple with pressures to conform to socially approved narratives. Ellison’s portrayal of identity as layered, contested, and evolving challenges simplistic understandings of race and individuality. By emphasizing self-reflection and resistance to external definitions, the novel invites readers to consider how they might be complicit in rendering others invisible—and how they might reclaim their own agency.

Conclusion

Ralph Ellison’s Invisible Man offers a profound exploration of identity, power, and the struggle for self-definition in a world structured by racial and ideological constraints. Through the narrator’s journey, Ellison demonstrates how institutions—from segregated educational systems to political movements—seek to shape individuals according to preconceived narratives. The protagonist’s invisibility emerges not from his own deficiencies but from society’s refusal to acknowledge his complexity. Yet Ellison insists that authentic identity can be forged through critical self-reflection and the rejection of imposed roles. The narrator’s movement from naïve obedience to self-awareness illustrates the painful but necessary process of constructing a self independent of external scripts. Ultimately, Invisible Man challenges readers to confront the forces that render others invisible and to consider how, like the narrator, they might step out of metaphorical basements to engage with the world on their own terms.

References

Ellison, Ralph. Invisible Man. Vintage International Edition, 1995.
