Classical and Modern Representations in O’Neill

Eugene O’Neill occupies a distinctive place in American dramatic history as both a modern innovator and a writer deeply invested in classical forms. His plays often return to ancient structures, myths, and theatrical traditions even as they explore the psychological fragmentation, social dislocation, and spiritual uncertainty of the twentieth century. This dual orientation—to the classical and the modern—shapes O’Neill’s dramatic universe, informing his characters’ inner lives, the architecture of his plots, and the philosophical reach of his tragedies. At the same time, it is O’Neill’s willingness to adapt classical motifs to modern contexts that gives his work its enduring immediacy and emotional force. He uses the foundational myths of Western culture not as objects of nostalgic reconstruction but as living frameworks through which to reinterpret the anxieties of his age.

This essay examines the intricate relationship between classical and modern representations in O’Neill’s dramaturgy, focusing in particular on three key works: Mourning Becomes Electra, The Iceman Cometh, and Long Day’s Journey into Night. Through these plays, O’Neill merges ancient narrative patterns with modernist psychology, reimagining fate, guilt, and familial conflict in a world no longer governed by divine order. His adaptations of Aristotelian tragedy, Greek myth, and classical determinism illuminate both the persistence of old narrative structures and the transformations required to make them meaningful in a society shaped by war, industrialization, and the disintegration of traditional religious certainties. Ultimately, O’Neill’s efforts reveal the tension at the heart of modern tragedy: the desire to restore classical coherence to a fragmented world, even as that world resists such unity.

Classical Foundations of O’Neill’s Dramaturgy

O’Neill’s fascination with classical tragedy began early in his career and intensified as he sought to elevate American drama beyond the conventions of melodrama and commercial entertainment. His reading of Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides convinced him that tragedy required both an elevated form and an exploration of fundamental human conflicts—particularly those involving family, guilt, and the inscrutability of fate. O’Neill envisioned American tragedy as a renewal rather than an imitation of ancient dramatic conventions. As he argued in interviews and letters, the Greek dramatists confronted the deepest questions of human existence, and he believed that modern drama needed to reclaim this ambition (Bogard, 1988). Yet he also recognized that twentieth-century audiences lived in a secular world without the metaphysical framework that had shaped ancient tragedy. The challenge, therefore, was to construct a tragic universe that could resonate emotionally and philosophically without relying on the divine machinery of classical drama.

To meet this challenge, O’Neill fused classical mythic patterns with modern psychological insight. His tragedies often depict characters trapped not by the will of the gods but by unconscious drives, inherited traumas, and internalized guilt. This modern psychological determinism functions as a secular analogue to fate, reflecting the influence of Freud, Jung, and emerging theories of psychoanalysis. At the same time, O’Neill employs structural elements associated with classical drama—choric commentary, symbolic motifs, heightened language, and cyclical narrative forms. These devices create an atmosphere of inevitability and gravitas reminiscent of Greek tragedy, even as the underlying forces shaping the characters’ destinies derive from social history, family legacy, or personal psychology.

The fusion of classical form and modern content reflects O’Neill’s belief that tragedy must evolve to remain vital. Rather than resurrecting a lost classical world, he uses its structural and thematic principles to interrogate the existential dilemmas of contemporary life. This approach is most visible in his adaptation of Aeschylus’s Oresteia cycle in Mourning Becomes Electra, but it also permeates his other major works, often in more subtle ways.

Classical Adaptation and Modern Family Trauma in Mourning Becomes Electra

Mourning Becomes Electra stands as O’Neill’s most explicit and ambitious engagement with classical tragedy. Modeled directly on the Oresteia, the play reimagines its ancient narrative of murder, revenge, and familial curse within the context of post-Civil War New England. O’Neill replaces the House of Atreus with the Mannon family, a clan marked by Puritan repression, generational guilt, and interpersonal distrust. By translating the myth into a North American setting, O’Neill demonstrates his belief that the forms of Greek tragedy continue to illuminate human experience when embedded within the social and psychological conditions of modern life.

The trilogy format he adopts—comprising The Homecoming, The Hunted, and The Haunted—mirrors Aeschylus’s structure, complete with parallel scenes, symbolic patterns, and recurring thematic motifs. Yet the differences between the two works underscore O’Neill’s modernist sensibility. While the Oresteia culminates in the establishment of justice and civic order, Mourning Becomes Electra offers no such resolution. The Mannons’ self-destruction leads not to social harmony but to psychological isolation and existential despair. Through this inversion, O’Neill critiques the possibility of transcendent meaning in a secular age.

One of the most striking features of O’Neill’s adaptation is the replacement of divine fate with psychological determinism. In Aeschylus, the gods drive the cycle of vengeance; in O’Neill, the characters’ unconscious desires, repressed emotions, and inherited patterns of guilt operate as the motivating forces. Christine Mannon’s affair with Adam Brant and the subsequent murder of Ezra Mannon unfold not as the fulfillment of a divine curse but as the inevitable eruption of years of emotional suffocation and marital disillusionment. Similarly, Orin’s descent into obsession and remorse derives from unresolved maternal attachment and wartime trauma. As critics have observed, O’Neill’s emphasis on psychological causation reflects the intellectual climate of his time, particularly the influence of psychoanalysis, but it also functions as a reinterpretation of classical fate as an internal rather than external force (Gelb & Gelb, 2000).

At the same time, O’Neill retains the classical conception of the family as the primary locus of tragedy. The Mannon household, like the House of Atreus, becomes a site of inherited trauma and cyclical violence. The physical environment—its rigid architecture, darkened rooms, and looming portrait of Ezra—operates as a modern counterpart to the mythic curse, symbolizing the oppressive weight of the past. Through these parallels, O’Neill demonstrates how classical tragedy can be translated into modern terms without losing its resonance.

Yet where Aeschylus ultimately embraces the possibility of justice and divine guidance, O’Neill’s world remains devoid of transcendence. Lavinia’s final self-imposed imprisonment symbolizes not the restoration of moral order but the bleak continuation of psychological bondage. Her retreat into isolation suggests that in the modern world, the tragic cycle can be recognized but not overcome. Thus, Mourning Becomes Electra serves as both homage and critique, revitalizing classical structures while exposing the inadequacy of ancient resolutions for contemporary existential dilemmas.

Modern Disillusionment and Classical Echoes in The Iceman Cometh

Although The Iceman Cometh is not based directly on a classical myth, it nonetheless incorporates classical tragic elements, particularly in its exploration of illusion, fate, and the human need for meaning. The setting—a seedy New York bar filled with the disillusioned and destitute—appears at first entirely modern and far removed from ancient dramatic landscapes. Yet the structure of the play, with its focus on the gradual revelation of truth and the catastrophic consequences of self-recognition, echoes the trajectory of classical tragedy.

At its core, The Iceman Cometh explores the destructive power of confronting the truth about oneself. The bar’s regular patrons survive through “pipe dreams,” fantasies that shield them from the oppressive realities of their lives. When Hickey, a traveling salesman, attempts to liberate them from these illusions, the results are catastrophic. His insistence on truth functions like the intervention of a tragic messenger, exposing the fragile foundations upon which the characters’ identities rest. The collapse of their illusions parallels the anagnorisis—the moment of recognition—in classical tragedy, but with a distinctly modern twist: rather than leading to enlightenment or moral clarity, the truth plunges the characters deeper into despair.

In this regard, O’Neill reimagines the tragic hero not as a noble figure brought low by hubris, but as an ordinary individual whose greatest suffering arises from existential awareness. Hickey himself becomes a kind of tragic figure, though he lacks the stature of a classical hero. His confession—that he killed his wife in an attempt to free her from the disappointment of his infidelities—reveals a distorted interpretation of liberation and love. His tragic flaw lies not in arrogance but in a misguided belief in the redemptive power of truth. By presenting illusion not simply as delusion but as a necessary component of survival, O’Neill questions the value of self-knowledge in a world devoid of transcendent meaning (Alexander, 2005).

The play’s structure, with its long monologues, rhythmic repetitions, and ritualistic unveiling of truth, echoes the ceremonial quality of classical drama. Yet it remains firmly grounded in modern concerns: the alienation of urban life, the psychological disintegration of individuals marginalized by social and economic forces, and the collapse of traditional systems of belief. In this sense, The Iceman Cometh demonstrates O’Neill’s ability to infuse classical tragic patterns into a distinctly modern context, suggesting that the human need for purpose and the terror of confronting its absence remain as relevant today as in ancient times.

Personal Myth and Aristotelian Tragedy in Long Day’s Journey into Night

While Long Day’s Journey into Night does not draw directly from classical myth, its tragic architecture bears unmistakable resemblance to Aristotelian principles. The play’s unity of time, its focus on a single extended family confrontation, and its emphasis on the interplay of fate and character align it with classical tragedy even as its autobiographical content and psychological realism anchor it in the modern world.

Central to the play’s classical resonance is its cyclical structure, which reflects the repetitive nature of familial trauma. The Tyrones are trapped in a pattern of accusation, regret, and self-justification that mirrors the inescapability of fate in Greek tragedy. Mary’s morphine addiction, James’s miserliness, and the sons’ alcoholism and illness appear both self-inflicted and predetermined, shaped by years of emotional neglect and economic anxiety. The result is a sense of tragic inevitability that pervades the play, suggesting that the characters are bound not by divine will but by personal history and psychological inheritance.

O’Neill’s portrayal of suffering as both internal and relational also parallels classical conceptions of tragic conflict. Like the royal houses of ancient drama, the Tyrones suffer not only from individual flaws but from the destructive dynamics of their family system. Their interactions reveal how deeply each character’s identity is entwined with the others, creating a web of mutual recrimination and dependence that resists resolution. This interconnectedness recalls the Greek emphasis on familial responsibility and collective suffering, but with a modern understanding of psychological trauma as a generational force (Sheaffer, 2002).

The play’s conclusion, with Mary retreating into a narcotic dream of her past, encapsulates the fusion of classical tragedy and modern despair. Unlike classical tragic recognition, which often leads to clarity or acceptance, Mary’s recognition leads only to further withdrawal. The absence of metaphysical resolution leaves the audience with a sense of unresolved tragedy, characteristic of modern drama’s rejection of closure. In this sense, Long Day’s Journey into Night becomes a meditation on the impossibility of redemption in a world where understanding does not guarantee transformation.

O’Neill’s Tragic Vision: Between Classical Order and Modern Fragmentation

Across his major works, O’Neill demonstrates a sustained engagement with the question of whether classical tragedy is possible in the modern era. He consistently employs classical structures and themes—fate, recognition, catharsis, familial curse—yet places them within a world governed by psychological drives rather than divine will. This approach reveals both his admiration for the classical tradition and his awareness of the philosophical challenges it faces in a secular age.

Modern tragedy, in O’Neill’s view, must confront the realities of psychological fragmentation, social alienation, and existential doubt. The decline of religious belief and the rise of scientific rationalism have complicated the notion of tragic fate, replacing divine causality with internal and societal forces. O’Neill does not reject the classical model; instead, he reconceptualizes it, suggesting that the tragic impulse persists even when the metaphysical foundations of ancient drama have eroded.

His characters struggle not against gods but against themselves, their pasts, and the structures of their environment. The result is a modern tragic vision that is simultaneously intimate and expansive, grounded in psychological realism but resonant with mythic significance. O’Neill’s tragedies thus bridge the gap between the ancient and the modern, demonstrating the continuing relevance of classical forms while acknowledging the profound shifts in human consciousness that define the twentieth century.

Conclusion

Eugene O’Neill’s work represents a unique and powerful fusion of classical tragedy and modern psychological drama. Through plays such as Mourning Becomes Electra, The Iceman Cometh, and Long Day’s Journey into Night, he reinterprets ancient themes for a world marked by disillusionment, fragmentation, and existential uncertainty. By adapting classical structures to modern contexts, O’Neill revitalizes the tragic form and demonstrates its enduring capacity to illuminate fundamental human struggles. His integration of psychological determinism, familial trauma, and existential doubt with the structural elegance of classical tragedy creates a body of work that is both historically grounded and profoundly contemporary. In O’Neill’s hands, the ancient and the modern converge, producing a dramatic vision that honors the past while grappling with the complexities of the present.

References

Bogard, T. (1988). Contour in Time: The Plays of Eugene O’Neill. Oxford University Press.

Gelb, A., & Gelb, B. (2000). O’Neill: Life with Monte Cristo. Applause Books.

Sheaffer, L. (2002). O’Neill: Son and Playwright. Little, Brown and Company.

TITLE: Margery Kempe's Self-Fashioning: Visioning Herself in God
HUMAN ESSAY:
Margery Kempe's Self-Fashioning: Visioning Herself in God

The Book of Margery Kempe, considered to be the first autobiography written in English, presents the story of a woman whose life is guided by visions of, and conversations with, God. By recounting her holy visions, she gains authority with Church officials and is able to travel widely across the known world. Margery (ca. 1373 –1440) is certainly an atypical woman1; she pays her husband's debts (Kempe, 60), composes her own autobiography despite illiteracy, and travels extensively without constant companionship of her husband. As James Brundage notes, medieval women – regardless of their social class – tended to live most of their lives in their homes (Brundage, 493), so to travel outside of England was quite an accomplishment on its own. In this context, and with the consideration of her self-description as a meek and passive woman, it seems puzzling, at first, that she was able to live such an active life and gain so much authority with Church officials across Europe and even in Jerusalem. This is not, however, the paradox that it may immediately seem to be. In fact, Margery's self-crafting and self-recitation of her divine visions provide the very allowance – both personal and external – that she needs in order to engage with the world as an active participant.

Throughout the narration of her incredibly active life, Margery rhetorically creates the sense that she makes no choices of her own, but is instead wholly guided by another – that is, God. Within the language she uses, she strips her own active agency from the narrative. When describing her many meetings with influential people, she writes that she uttered many good words as God would put them into her mind(Kempe, 61). The words she speaks are God's, not her own. Even her abundance of tears come from without herself; she tells the reader that, in a vision, God commanded, you may not have tears … except when God will send them to you, for they are the free gifts of God, distinct from your merit (66). From the beginning of The Book, Margery describes inhabitation or possession; her hysteria and sinful nature are caused by the presence of an inner demon who acts upon her. She posits a simple cause-and-effect relationship for her actions:

[T]he devils called out to her with great threats, and bade her that she should forsake her Christian faith and belief, and deny her God, his mother, and all the saints in heaven, her good works and all good virtues, her father, her mother, and all her friends. And so she did. […] just as the spirits tempted her to say and do, so she said and did (42).

Here, Margery narrates her obedience to the commands of her possessors. Despite the costs – God, family, virtue – she explains that she does exactly what was asked of her, with no objection. She is a being who is fully under another's control. Even in her pious life, her piety is not for any specific choice she makes, but because Christ had worked his grace in her (43) and gave her great devotion (108). She fits this narrative perfectly into the model set before her of how to receive visions: almost all of her advisors tell her to be obedient to the will of our Lord and fulfill with all her might whatever he put[s] into her soul (78), and to be humble and meek (80) in her role as a medium. As Margery describes it, her life includes very little deliberate agency, and consists of obedience, rather than choice.

Margery goes even further than demonstrating voluntary obedience – she explains that, even if she wanted to exercise control over her own actions, it would not be possible. In Jerusalem, she could not keep herself from crying and roaring though she should have died for it, and that she fell down because she could not stand or kneel, but writhed and wrestled with her body 2 (104). In her telling, she is not responsible for her tears, convulsions, her physical responses, because they come not from herself. The reader is led to conceive of her as a vessel for God's choices, with no available means or alternatives to what He wants of her. Even her obedience is inactive and in no way volitional. She does not even own the fundamental self-control that allows the agency of choice.

This image, however, is self-consciously crafted. Margery narrates in the third person and refers to herself only as the creature, distancing herself from the act of composing the manuscript. This creates rhetorical distance from the kind of narcissistic authority that is often found in autobiographical writings, and would undermine her position as an obedient conduit for God's word. The phrase the creature implies an artistic act external to that creature – there is a creator, God, and a created-one, Margery. With each self-reference as such, she implicitly emphasizes that the relevant artistic act is not of a narrative, not of an autobiography, but of the ultimate act of creation: human life. Whatever her motives for this self-naming,3 the result is that attention is diverted from the inherently active nature of composing a text, and Margery is, again, the passive object of creation, rather than the active subject of her own autobiography and life.

If we reconceive her rhetorical crafting of this story, we can read the shifted agency not as essential female passivity, but as a way for an illiterate medieval woman to gain control over aspects of her life. Because she is not responsible for her actions, nothing that she does or says can be her fault. Those who criticize her actions or physical responses are immediately cast as heretical; her word is inseparable from the word of God. She has permission to travel widely in God's name, to speak with Church officials in private chambers, even to challenge their own piety to their faces.4 Margery's critics malign her for wearing all white, but she reports that God tells her, you shall dress according to my will (67) and that she dared not do otherwise than as she was commanded in her soul (68). Through reporting her vision, she can actively counter the assumption that she is a troublesome, self-intentioned woman, and provide divine documentation that she is, instead, fulfilling the proper role for a medieval woman: obedience. For a reader or companion who shares her values, this obedience is necessarily lauded as obedience to God, despite her overt and insistent disobedience to her male companions. Her vision frees her from the burden of self-responsibility or accountability for this earthly disobedience. Divine authority also allows her to offer rebuttals, such as when a Bishop tells her to wait to return from Jerusalem to take her vow of chastity, and she counters his assessment as she had been commanded [by the Lord] (70-71). The narration of her visions gives her permission to act in a strikingly forward manner, despite the veneer of being a mere, meek receptacle.

Margery's manner of telling is also a strategy by which she accesses control over her audience from within the text. She massages the reader's perception, deliberately guiding them to a sense of her as pious and obedient, even when the underlying facts belie that impression. The most overt example of textual manipulation in her Book is a parenthetical note at the close of the sixteenth chapter, which says, Read first the twenty-first chapter and then this chapter after that (73). To the modern reader – and likely to one of her contemporary literate readers – this is a crude stylistic device. But in as disjointed and episodic a text as this one, in which there is no overarching literary form, such fashioning must be considered as a deliberate and thoughtful attempt at rhetorical manipulation. With the textual leap to chapter twenty-one comes the announcement of a seemingly abrupt pregnancy, perhaps meant to evoke an immaculate conception. This pregnancy, in fact, begins with a divine annunciation, much like the Biblical Immaculate Conception. In a revelation, our Lord said to [Margery], Daughter, you are with child (84). The chapter proceeds through a vision in which Margery communes with God and the Virgin Mary, who both praise Margery for her pregnancy. God tells her that this pregnancy is no sin, and they both laud her and validate this conception (84-85). Margery, in this vision, is aligned directly with Mary Magdalene […] Mary of Egypt, St Paul, and many other saints that are now in heaven, and less directly – through repeated mentions of God's own blessed mother – the Virgin Mary (85). These reminders of the Virgin Birth and praise of Margery's virtue blatantly demonstrate to the reader that God Himself considers this conception a blessing.

Chapter seventeen tells a different story, however. In the very first sentence of the chapter, Margery writes of giving birth to her other children and of a visit from God in which He tells her that she should bear no more children (73). This seemingly unequivocal decree, though, seems all but irrelevant by the time the reader finally returns to chapter seventeen. By crafting the reader's movement through the text, Margery virtually bypasses this information without omission. She skips reminding the reader of her previous children – the reference of which would undermine the effect of the rhetorically abrupt pregnancy as well as the correlation to the Virgin Mary – and also prepares the reader for her becoming pregnant before revealing that Jesus commanded her not to. The reader already knows how happy God is to see Margery with child at the point that he or she reads the commandment not to become pregnant again. By interrupting the chronology of this narrative, Margery avoids presenting herself as disobedient of God's commandment not to bear any more children, as she undoubtedly would if the events were placed in their proper chronology.

Beyond a rhetorical level, Margery's visions also benefit her own emotional life. One function of her visions is that they allow her to develop an interpersonally intimate relationship that is more symbiotic than her relationship with her husband. The kindest words Margery has for her husband come in the first chapter, when she says that he always had tenderness and compassion for her (43). After this, however, he is not presented as an emotional mate, but rather as a barrier to her holiness, insisting that they have sexual encounters against her will. When she refuses, he tells her, You are no good wife (58). At one point on her travels simply writes she did not know where her husband had gone (64). He largely falls into the background of her story, literally disappearing for years. In an early conversation with God, she says that she would choose her priest as her companion to heaven more than [her] own father or [her] husband (55). From this, it is fair to assume that Margery and her husband had a tense, possibly even antagonistic, relationship, as she likely saw him as the embodiment of her sexual sins, even as someone who would be willing to put her life at risk for his own sexual pleasures,5 and for his part, we at least know that he expects more from her in fulfilling the obligations of marriage. Medieval marriages were not necessarily loveless,6 but love was not requisite to the marriage, and tended to grow out of the conjugal debts, according to John T. Noonan, who quotes Thomas: a man loves his wife principally by reason of the carnal meeting (Noonan, 255). The carnal meetings that Margery and her husband share, however, do not strengthen Margery's relationship with her husband, and rather than contributing to a developing love, they are a source of anguish and tension.

In contrast, Margery's visions bring her into a symbiosis with God that is more akin to the language and sentiment of marriage than anything she speaks of her husband. In her visions, she and Christ are bonded. God expresses to her many times that they are a unit, saying, I am in you, and you in me (Kempe, 57). This is a statement that can be read as sexual, Eucharistic, and also familial. To integrate all three of these modes of reading this complicated image, the repeating image is simply that of mutual communion with the Lord, in which He is just as eager to take her body into His. The reciprocity of their relationship even inverts the directionality of expected devotional writing (in which Margery would promise penance to God), and Margery narrates that God tells her, if it were possible for me to suffer pain again as I have done before, I would rather suffer as much as I ever did for your soul alone, rather than that you should be separated from me without end (65-66). The singularity – and emotional dependence – with which God devotes Himself to Margery is as startling as it is affectionate. He tells her that wherever she goes, he go[es] with her, including both to church and to bed; their togetherness spans both night and day (66). This resembles a domestic marriage more than it resembles the expected Christian understanding of God's devotion to mankind. Noonan, citing a 13th century monk and theologian, writes, In marriage there is a certain singleness of love in which an outsider does not share … There is mutual love and therefore mutual zeal, and therefore singleness (Noonan, 256). This is entirely consistent with Margery's narration of God's expressions of love to her. God tells her that she is a love unlike any other (86). He repeats the word singular many times to describe how particularized his love for her is, as she is his own blessed spouse (88). God expresses a mutual and singular love for Margery, giving her access to a mutually beneficial and enriching relationship that she would otherwise not have. The benefits of such a relationship are not found in any text, but are arguably located within Margery's continued energy and determination to continue on her journey.

Margery not only allows herself to feel loved and cared for through her visions, she also finds emotional validation and familial comfort from heavenly voices. When she feels inadequate or fears that she is in danger, a holy voice intervenes to soothe her. While fearing attack on her travels, God says to her with paternal assurance, Don't be afraid, daughter, your party will come to no harm while you are in their company (98). St. Anne and Elizabeth also refer to her as daughter in an anxious moment, Anne telling the disheartened Margery, I am well pleased with your service, and Elizabeth, it seems to me that you do your duty very well (53). God enters when Margery doubts herself, and tells her that he loves her, or that she has no reason to be afraid or troubled. Within the narrative, Margery is calmed by these familial and intimate appeals, and on another level, they provide divine authority that Margery very rarely does wrong in the eyes of God. Her visions are soothing voices, quelling her angst about her own life – and serving the additional purpose of convincing the reader that her angst and self-criticism are unfounded.

Margery's state of mind is relevant in that the visions provide her with an internal opportunity to circumvent the messages she receives from many external critics of her devotion and lifestyle. Along her spiritual journey, skeptics and believers alike question her and her visions. Even the priest who served as the scribe of her book finds it necessary to test her feelings, and for a long time would not always give credence to her words (91). She repeatedly has to persuade those whom she meets to believe her. One of her confessors is very sharp with [her, and] considers [her visions] merely trifles and jokes (80). The assumption going into a situation with unfamiliar people is that they will not believe [her] words, which results in this creature [Margery] suffer[ing] a great deal of tribulation and unhappiness (81) because of the difficult nature of being a self-proclaimed mystic. Without the emotional security from the visions, Margery would likely not have the boldness and endurance to continue to do so. The validation she receives from the visions, then, can be read as responses of empowerment to continue living her life as she has been: she affirms from within that she is doing the right thing and has the emotional support and singular love of God.

From a critical standpoint, it is worth examining what Margery has to gain from these visions, even for a wholly trusting reader. The content and rhetoric of the visions tend to cohere into an extremely self-serving model, even in moments when Margery describes her own overwhelming misery. Through envisioning a complex familial, sexual, and devotional relationship with God, Margery gives herself permission to love, to do, and to feel. More tangibly, Margery's visions allow her to lead an active life, to travel and engage in significant theological discourses with important people, to have influence on people's faith, and to grant herself her own emotion fulfillment – all while fitting her behavior into the expectation that she should be, above all else, obedient and passive. If we were to extend the hypothesis into the purely speculative, and assume briefly that Margery is fully conscious of the crafting of her story with only selfish motivations, the means by which she achieved the desired ends would be incredibly close – if not identical – to what she narrates in her Book. Working within the prescribed role of obedience to God, she finds incredible self-assurance, activity, and self-possession. However, even without assuming such a fundamental dishonesty on Margery's part, it is fair to presume that these visions were – even subconsciously – a self-fashioned way of entering and engaging with the world in a more desirable way.

Works Cited
Brundage, James. “Sex, Marriage, and the Law from the Black Death to the Reformation, 1348-1517.” In Law, Sex, and Christian Society in Medieval Europe, 487-550. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1987.
Kempe, Margery. Selection from Book of Margery Kempe. Translated by B. A. Windeatt. London: Penguin, 1994.
Noonan, John T. “The Rationale of the Prohibition.” In Contraception: A History of Its Treatment by the Catholic Theologians and Canonists, 231-257. Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1986.
AI ESSAY:
Margery Kempe’s Self-Fashioning: Visioning Herself in God

Introduction

Margery Kempe’s Book stands as one of the most complex, enigmatic, and self-consciously crafted pieces of life writing to emerge from late medieval England. Long interpreted as a confessional narrative or devotional autobiography, the Book functions simultaneously as a theological testimony, a spiritual memoir, a travel narrative, a defense of mystical authority, and, crucially, an instrument of authorial self-fashioning. Kempe, a laywoman without formal education and without monastic enclosure, ventures boldly into a literary and spiritual landscape dominated by clerical voices. Her voice, mediated through her scribes, constructs a persona that is at once humble and assertive, illiterate yet rhetorically sophisticated, submissive to ecclesiastical structures yet radically independent in spiritual experience. The Book thus becomes a site in which Kempe fashions herself as a visionary mystic whose identity is not simply described but actively produced through narrative, revelation, and dialogic performance with God, clerics, and lay communities.

This essay argues that Margery Kempe’s self-fashioning emerges through a sustained process of visioning herself in God: an imaginative and rhetorical alignment of her identity with divine perception. By situating herself within divine sight—seeing God and being seen by God—Kempe transforms her unstable social position into a spiritually authoritative one. Her visionary encounters, affective piety, and incessant weeping become not merely devotional episodes but strategies by which she crafts a public spiritual persona. Moreover, Kempe’s book functions as a theological apparatus asserting that God writes her identity upon her soul, making her simultaneously the subject and the object of divine narrative. Her self-fashioning is thus grounded in the tension between humility and authority, orthodoxy and transgression, agency and submission. Through close analysis of her visionary experiences, her relationship to clerical power, her bodily performances, and her textual self-representation, this essay demonstrates how Kempe constructs a self made legible—and legitimate—only through God’s regard.

Self-Fashioning, Vision, and Medieval Female Spirituality

To understand Kempe’s self-fashioning, one must consider the broader medieval context in which visionary women often navigated the paradox of being spiritually authoritative while socially marginal. Drawing on traditions reflected in texts like Julian of Norwich’s Revelations and Bridget of Sweden’s Revelations, Kempe situates herself within the lineage of holy women who spoke with Christ, experienced intense affective devotion, and challenged conventional boundaries between laity and clergy. Yet Kempe differs from these women in her lack of enclosure, lack of education, and late turn to a devotional life following marriage and motherhood. Her self-fashioning therefore depends not on institutional or textual prestige but on experiential authority grounded in divine encounter.

The problem of female authority in the late Middle Ages was acute. Women mystics often justified their outspokenness by claiming divine command, insistence on obedience, or rhetorical self-deprecation. Kempe’s Book employs all these strategies. She consistently foregrounds her ignorance, her unworthiness, and her dependence on God’s grace, which paradoxically bolsters her authority by emphasizing that her knowledge and visions cannot stem from her natural faculties. Her illiteracy becomes a theological claim: she is a vessel God chooses precisely because she cannot author herself through intellectual means. Instead, God authorizes her through revelation. In this way, Kempe’s self-fashioning is inseparable from the visionary mode. To see God is to be validated by God, and to be seen by God is to be written into divine narrative.

This double dynamic—seeing God and being seen—structures her subjectivity. At various moments, she depicts herself as gazing upon Christ’s humanity, especially his passion, while simultaneously being gazed upon and addressed by Christ as his beloved daughter, chosen for a special mission. Through this relational dynamic, Kempe fashions a spiritual identity grounded not in social or linguistic capital but in divine intimacy. The rhetoric of vision thus becomes the rhetoric of selfhood.

Visionary Encounters as Sites of Identity Construction

Kempe’s visions are not merely affective experiences but narrative moments in which she constructs the contours of her spiritual self. These episodes allow her to insert herself into salvation history, to model herself upon biblical figures, and to position herself as a chosen recipient of divine revelation. Early in the Book, Christ tells her that she is uniquely loved: “Daughter, why weepest thou so sore?” (Kempe 43). This question, echoing scriptural resurrection dialogues, positions her not only as one who experiences Christ but also as one who reenacts sacred scenes. Her excessive weeping, often criticized by onlookers, becomes a sacramental sign through which she embodies the emotional truths of the Passion.

Such visionary scenes establish her as a privileged witness. When Christ tells her, “Thou art a singular lover and I am thy lover” (Kempe 52), Kempe is cast in a bridal mysticism framework traditionally associated with nuns. By situating herself in the role of Christ’s spiritual spouse, she claims a form of sanctified intimacy unavailable to most laypeople. The vision is not simply an emotional consolation; it becomes the foundation of an identity that authorizes her to speak and act in ways that challenge social expectations for married laywomen.

Moreover, these visions function as vertical counterpoints to the horizontal opposition she receives from clerics, neighbors, and travel companions. When human figures attempt to silence or shame her, Christ’s visionary affirmations override their authority. For example, after a priest questions her orthodoxy, Christ reassures her: “Dread thee not, daughter; I shall answer for thee verily” (Kempe 106). In these moments, Kempe’s identity is stabilized through divine discourse. Her self-fashioning thus emerges through dialogic interaction: she becomes the Margery Kempe Christ describes, validates, and protects.

These visionary episodes both reflect and produce her sense of self. By narrating them, she inscribes herself into a divine-human relationship that is the core of her identity. The Book not only records these visions but performs their meaning by showing how they shape her behavior, her public piety, and her ongoing struggle for spiritual authority. Through vision, she sees herself in God, and through narration, she fashions herself for readers.

Affective Piety and Bodily Performance as Self-Fashioning

Margery Kempe’s distinctive form of affective piety—marked most notably by her loud weeping, wailing, and physical convulsions—functions as both a devotional practice and a performative strategy of self-fashioning. While modern readers may interpret these behaviors as psychological symptoms or social disruptions, within the spiritual logic of the Book, they serve as embodied manifestations of divine intimacy and emotional participation in Christ’s suffering. Kempe’s tears are not passive expressions of emotion; they are active articulations of identity.

Her weeping is explicitly tied to Christ’s instruction. When criticized for her tears, Kempe insists that they result from divine command: “For the weping that thou wepest is not of thyself but of the gift of the Holy Ghost” (Kempe 117). This assertion shifts agency from her body to God’s will. The tears, then, become external signs of internal grace. They enable her to present herself as a vessel of divine emotion, someone whose body enacts God’s presence rather than personal indulgence.

Through this bodily performance, Kempe constructs a public identity recognizable to late medieval audiences familiar with affective spirituality. The dramatic gestures mirror the devotional practices encouraged in meditative texts such as the Meditations on the Life of Christ, which urged readers to imagine Christ’s Passion so vividly that emotional overflow became spiritually meaningful. Kempe amplifies this norm, embodying an extreme form of devotion that both marks her as spiritually gifted and places her at odds with social expectations.

Her bodily performances also challenge conventional boundaries of authority. Medieval women often faced suspicion when expressing spiritual authority publicly, but Kempe reframes her disruptive behavior as obedience to God rather than rebellion against clerical structures. When she is arrested or interrogated, she appeals not to reasoned argument but to God’s direct prompting. This appeal repositions her body as a testimonial text written by God. The body becomes the site through which divine authorship enacts itself, allowing her to circumvent her illiteracy and lack of theological training.

Additionally, the extremity of Kempe’s affective piety constructs her as a liminal figure. She is neither enclosed nun nor typical laywoman; neither silent contemplative nor strictly public preacher. Her oscillation between domesticity, pilgrimage, and ecstatic performance reflects a fluid identity shaped by continual negotiation with divine will. In this sense, her body serves as a dynamic medium of self-fashioning, continually reshaped by the tension between God’s demands and communal norms.

Kempe’s performance of weeping ultimately constitutes a somatic rhetoric, a bodily language through which she asserts her spiritual identity. She becomes legible to others not through theological discourse but through embodied signs that align her with Christ’s suffering. Her tears allow her to vision herself in God by participating bodily in the divine narrative.

Dialogue with Clerical Authority

No analysis of Margery Kempe’s self-fashioning can overlook her relationship with clerical authority. Her interactions with priests, bishops, friars, and theologians form a major portion of the Book, and these encounters function as crucibles in which her identity is tested, contested, and ultimately reinforced. Through these conflicts, Kempe fashions herself as both obedient daughter of the Church and divinely authorized visionary who occasionally defies ecclesiastical norms.

Many clerics view her with suspicion, interpreting her tears and divine revelations as signs of Lollardy, madness, or spiritual presumption. Yet Kempe consistently positions herself as orthodox, humble, and guided by God. When examined by the Archbishop of York, she responds to accusations by emphasizing her adherence to Church doctrine: “I believe in all the sacraments of Holy Church” (Kempe 157). Her orthodoxy becomes a key element of her self-fashioning, essential for distinguishing herself from heretical movements.

At the same time, Kempe often asserts a higher form of authority: divine command superseding clerical skepticism. In one episode, when a friar challenges her right to speak publicly of God, Christ instructs her inwardly, “Say boldly that I shall speak for thee” (Kempe 160). This divine backing transforms what could be an act of disobedience into one of higher obedience. The tension between clerical oversight and divine authorization thus becomes a narrative engine propelling her identity formation.

Moreover, Kempe strategically aligns herself with sympathetic clerics who validate her experiences. The Carmelite friar who affirms her tears as the work of the Holy Spirit becomes a crucial support for her self-understanding. His endorsement positions her within orthodox mystical tradition rather than on its margins. Similarly, her interactions with learned men in Jerusalem, Rome, and Prussia demonstrate her willingness to expose her visions to ecclesiastical scrutiny, allowing authoritative assessment to sharpen the contours of her spiritual self.

The clerical dialogues in the Book contribute to Kempe’s self-fashioning by displaying her rhetorical flexibility. She alternates between humility and assertiveness, silence and bold speech, always framing her responses as obedience to God. This positioning allows her to participate in discursive arenas typically denied to laywomen. Her ability to negotiate these interactions, often successfully, demonstrates how her identity as a visionary is constructed not only through encounters with God but through the social validation and resistance she receives within ecclesiastical structures.

Kempe’s self-fashioning thus emerges as a complex interplay between submission and defiance. She seeks clerical approval but does not consider it the ultimate source of authority. Instead, clerics serve as earthly interlocutors who confirm, challenge, and refine the identity she ultimately receives from God. Through these interactions, Kempe positions herself as both obedient daughter of Holy Church and chosen vessel whose authority originates in divine encounter.

Pilgrimage and Narrative Identity

Pilgrimage constitutes another central dimension of Kempe’s self-fashioning. Her extensive travels—to Jerusalem, Rome, Santiago de Compostela, and various European shrines—provide a geographical canvas upon which her spiritual transformation unfolds. These journeys serve not merely as physical movements but as narrative episodes in which Kempe negotiates identity, community, and divine calling.

Pilgrimage allows Kempe to perform holiness publicly. As she travels, she encounters diverse audiences—pilgrims, priests, merchants, householders—who witness her tears, her ecstatic speech, and her devotional intensity. These encounters function as opportunities for Kempe to test, display, and further craft her spiritual persona. When other pilgrims mock her for her excessive weeping, she interprets this opposition as a sign of spiritual authenticity, aligning herself with Christ’s suffering and the persecuted saints. Her endurance of ridicule becomes part of her identity narrative.

Moreover, pilgrimage liberates Kempe from the constraints of domestic life. As a married woman with fourteen children, her departure from home represents a renegotiation of her social role. She gains mobility, spiritual purpose, and opportunities to establish her identity outside familial expectations. This mobility also places her in liminal spaces—ships, roads, foreign cities—where traditional hierarchies are softened and spiritual encounters are intensified. In these spaces, she continues to vision herself in God through prayer, tears, and visionary reassurance.

Narratively, pilgrimage allows Kempe to position herself within biblical typology. Journeying to Jerusalem, she participates in the sacred geography of salvation history. At the Holy Sepulchre, she experiences intense affective visions that link her bodily presence to Christ’s Passion (Kempe 193). These moments grant her identity cosmic significance. She is not merely a traveler but a witness to the sites of divine revelation, a participant in the reenactment of sacred history.

Furthermore, pilgrimage structures the Book itself, providing a loose chronological framework for her spiritual development. As she moves across landscapes, her identity evolves, shaped by new trials, companions, and divine encounters. The narrative’s episodic nature mirrors her fluctuating sense of self, which stabilizes only through Christ’s continual affirmations. Thus, pilgrimage becomes a metaphor for self-fashioning: a movement from spiritual instability toward divine-centered identity.

Finally, pilgrimage offers Kempe opportunities to engage with international clerical communities. Her interviews with Italian friars, German priests, and Jerusalem guides broaden her spiritual network and validate her experiences. Each encounter further integrates her into a transnational Christian community, strengthening the spiritual identity she forges through divine vision.

In sum, pilgrimage serves as a vital mechanism for Kempe’s self-fashioning, enabling her to inhabit sacred spaces, encounter new audiences, and repeatedly reaffirm her identity in God.

Dictation, Illiteracy, and the Construction of Authorship

Margery Kempe’s illiteracy is one of the most striking features of her self-representation, and it plays a crucial role in her self-fashioning. Although illiteracy might seem to limit her authority, Kempe turns it into a theological asset. By insisting that she cannot write, she underscores her dependence on divine inspiration and clerical mediation, which paradoxically enhances her spiritual credibility. Rather than diminishing her authorship, illiteracy reshapes it, enabling Kempe to construct an identity grounded in divine authorship rather than human literary skill.

Kempe’s reliance on scribes creates a layered narrative voice. She refers to herself as “this creature,” a third-person designation that fosters humility while also suggesting a crafted literary persona. This linguistic choice diminishes her direct authorial presence while simultaneously emphasizing her special ontological status as a creature fashioned by God. The self she presents is therefore divinely authored, not self-authored in a conventional literary sense.

The process of dictation also mirrors the process of divine revelation. Just as God speaks to Kempe inwardly, she speaks to her scribe outwardly. Her words are mediated, transcribed, and shaped by another, creating an analogy between divine authorship of her soul and scribal authorship of her book. In this parallel, the Book becomes a textual embodiment of her spiritual experience. Her self-fashioning thus depends on a unique collaboration between human and divine voices.

Furthermore, dictation allows Kempe to claim humility while still producing an ambitious narrative. Her insistence that she is not responsible for the book’s composition frees her from accusations of pride, intellectual presumption, or literary ambition—charges that often troubled medieval women writers. Instead, she frames the Book as an act of obedience to God’s command: “Write thy feelings and thy revelations, for it is my will” (Kempe 225). The narrative becomes a divine mandate, and its creation becomes a sign of her spiritual election.

The editorial structure of the Book—with its multiple revisions, corrections, and additions—also contributes to her self-fashioning. The text itself mirrors her turbulent spiritual journey, marked by moments of clarity and confusion, stability and disruption. The fragmented composition process reflects her unstable identity, which is continually reshaped by divine vision. Yet the final product presents a coherent portrayal of a woman who has achieved spiritual transformation through divine authorship.

Through her illiteracy and reliance on dictation, Kempe fashions herself as a prophet-like figure whose authority is grounded not in textual mastery but in divine inspiration. Her authorship becomes a form of spiritual witness, enabling her to assert identity in a medium traditionally reserved for the literate elite. In this way, illiteracy becomes not a limitation but a defining feature of her self in God.

Theological Implications of Being Seen by God

Margery Kempe’s self-fashioning cannot be fully understood without examining her insistence on being seen by God. Her visions often describe Christ looking at her, speaking to her, or revealing his emotions toward her. This divine gaze is not passive; it actively constructs her identity. In medieval theology, God’s sight was associated with knowledge, judgment, and love. To be seen by God meant to be truly known, forgiven, and guided.

For Kempe, divine vision becomes the ultimate validation. Human observers misunderstand, ridicule, or condemn her, but God sees her truth. This dynamic creates a clear hierarchy of perception: earthly witnesses misread her actions, but divine vision perceives her rightly. Thus, Kempe’s self-fashioning relies on privileging God’s gaze over human judgment.

One recurrent theme in her visions is Christ addressing her as “daughter,” a designation that confers spiritual authority and familial intimacy. This divine naming constructs her as someone with a unique identity in the divine order. She is not merely a sinner seeking forgiveness but a beloved child entrusted with special understanding. The emotional resonance of being called “daughter” shapes her self-perception, grounding her identity in relational intimacy with God.

Being seen by God also allows Kempe to reinterpret her sufferings as spiritually meaningful. When she is mocked or imprisoned, she recalls Christ’s words affirming her worth. This divine regard reframes her social humiliation as participation in Christ’s own suffering. Thus, divine vision becomes the lens through which she interprets her life.

Furthermore, divine sight justifies her public actions. When people question her weeping, she asserts that Christ sees the truth of her devotion. This perspective emboldens her to continue practices that seem socially disruptive. The divine gaze becomes a moral compass guiding her behavior.

Ultimately, being seen by God provides Kempe with the stable identity that earthly society denies her. She is a woman whose sense of self emerges not from social roles, marital obligations, or communal approval but from her intimate relationship with divine perception. Her self-fashioning is therefore inseparable from the theological conviction that God knows her fully and lovingly.

Conclusion

Margery Kempe’s Book offers a rich and intricate portrayal of a woman who constructs her identity through visionary experience, embodied devotion, negotiation with clerical authority, and the theological conviction of being known by God. Her self-fashioning emerges through the dynamic interplay between divine revelation and social resistance, between bodily performance and textual mediation, between humility and assertion. By visioning herself in God—seeing God and being seen by God—Kempe fashions a self that challenges the boundaries of gender, literacy, and religious authority in late medieval England.

Her visionary encounters shape her identity as a chosen soul; her affective piety transforms her body into a site of divine authorship; her interactions with clerics refine her spiritual authority; her pilgrimages provide a narrative framework for spiritual transformation; and her dictation process maps divine authorship onto textual creation. In all these ways, Kempe constructs a self that is grounded not in worldly validation but in divine intimacy.

Margery Kempe’s self-fashioning is thus an act of theological creativity. She becomes, in her own words, “a creature” fashioned by God, yet she also becomes a narrative agent who shapes how that divine authorship is perceived. Her Book stands as a testament to the power of visionary imagination to construct identity, to challenge social limits, and to inscribe the self within the divine gaze. Through visioning herself in God, Margery Kempe offers a model of spiritual subjectivity that remains compelling for scholars and readers alike.
