TITLE: Charity in Sir Thornhill
HUMAN ESSAY:
Charity in the Character of Sir William Thornhill

In the novel, The Vicar of Wakefield by Oliver Goldsmith, one man describes Sir William Thornhill as a man who has the first character in the kingdom for every thing that is just and good (136). Others, throughout the novel, make similar protestations of his goodness. However, for a character supposedly so good and decent, he does not take the actions he should in preventing his friends’, the Primroses, downfall. Similarly, he does not show as many instances of charity one would expect from someone considered so charitable (19). By taking a closer look at Sir William’s character, it is clear that he is not as deserving as everyone in the novel believes he is of the many kind descriptions attributed to him, and as a friend, he leaves much to be desired.

Sir William states of himself, At present, his bounties are more rational and moderate than before; but still he preserves the character of an humourist, and finds most pleasure in eccentric virtues (20). Yet, after having not given up charity completely when realizing his previous mistakes, it is hard to understand why Sir William would not show more charity to his friends, the Primroses, especially since right after their meeting the Vicar tells him of their late misfortunes (18). In fact, other than saving Sophia, an act that actually requires no charity, saving a dog stealer, and the money he spends at the end of the novel, he performs no charitable acts. All of the charity ascribed to him was done in the past, and for a man supposedly given to reckless charity, it is hard to believe there would not be more instances with regards to his new friends.

In addition to hardly showing charity to his friends, he takes from them. It would be one thing if he went around masquerading as poor while never taking from others less fortunate than himself, but he does take from others. When Sir William is first seen in the novel, he is asking for money from the inn keeper and then after being denied, is given money by the Vicar (18). These people all have less than he does so it seems unkind to accept from them money that they need more than he does, especially when the Vicar has six children. Sir William states that he is glad that a late oversight in giving what money I had about me, has shewn me that there are still some men like you (18). Surely, though, he could observe charity in the world while still not taking from others. Later, as his visits to the Primroses become more frequent, he begins helping them in the field, which to a degree makes up for his taking from them, yet it is hard to believe he would not offer more to them than gingerbread and boxes, especially given the many hardships the family faces as the novel progresses (54).

While these instances are important in noting how is character is not quite as worthy of the titles he is given, they in no way proves it as much as his unkindness to the Primrose family does in not taking further means to prevent Olivia from being seduced by his nephew, Mr. Thornhill. At the end, Sir Williams says to the Vicar, It is impossible…that I should forgive you, as you never deserved my resentment. I partly saw your delusion then, and as it was out of my power to restrain, I could only pity it! (149). This is not true. It was certainly not out of his power to restrain (149). He could have done any number of things to prevent this from happening. Sir William could have further told the Primroses of Mr. Thornhill’s villainy, or he could have revealed himself as Sir William if they needed further proof, or he could have simply forbid his nephew from acting the way he acted or cut off his money. Surely, by then he had known enough of the Primroses’ benevolence to give up his masquerade for something as important as saving their daughter. The fact that he did not and only pitied them is both cruel and selfish. A truly charitable person would go out of their way no matter what the cost to save friends.

This seduction and removal from her family was no small matter. It was only by chance that the Vicar found Olivia. What if she had not made it back? What if she had starved to death? The danger to more than just her character was simply too high for Sir William to ignore, although saving her character alone still should have been enough to induce him to intervene. Furthermore, if his refusal to take further measures was only out of indignation because of his previous fight with the family, or to teach them a lesson, then is was too unkind a lesson.

Sir William says at the end of the novel, of his nephew’s actions, Good heavens! How every new discovery alarms me, which could provide proof that he did not know the lengths to which his nephew would go to satisfy his lust, but that is hard to believe as well (158). Olivia says to her father that Sir William took every opportunity of privately admonishing me against the artifices of Mr. Thornhill, who I now find was even worse than he represented him (109). Knowing that Mr. Thornhill had artifices at all makes it hard to accept that Sir William did not know the full length of his nephew’s artifices (109). Even if he did not know the full lengths to which Mr. Thornhill would go, there is really no acceptable length for letting someone, let alone a friend, be fooled. In other words, apprehensions are apprehensions and no matter how small, if he had reason to believe something bad would happen then that should have been enough to persuade him to take a stronger course of action. He should have also notified the entire family of Mr. Thornhill’s character. If Olivia was in love with Mr. Thornhill, then it is not hard to believe that she would not act on or believe his warnings. Granted his letter did show the Primroses his disagreement with Olivia and Sophia’s trip to London, but he did not explain or defend his actions, and it is natural that they should think his disagreement was based on his love for Sophia (68-69). Furthermore, the Vicar states, So saying, I threw him his pocket-book, which he took up with a smile, and shutting the clasps with the utmost composure, left us, quite astonished at the serenity of his assurance (68). It is hard to believe him kind when he smiles, because he knows they do not know all that he does about Thornhill’s character; therefore, he has to suspect that something bad might happen. In addition to that, it is hard to believe a true friend would leave people he cares about so easily and without defending his actions. It seems as though that would have been the perfect time to reveal his true identity, saving everyone so much pain.

There is other proof throughout the novel that Sir William knew more about his nephew than he leads on at the end. For example, when George goes to get help from Sir William after having fought in a duel for Mr. Thornhill, Sir William calls him the instrument of his vices (97). This means that not only does he know his nephew gets into duels, but he then must also know there is a reason behind all of these duels. Furthermore, Sir William’s lack of surprise at someone like George showing up and asking for help further confirms he knows what types of things his nephew gets into. In addition to this instance, Sir William repeatedly says fudge! to the two ladies employed by Mr. Thornhill to deceive the Primroses. Although he might be saying, fudge, because he does not care for their characters or because he does not want the Primroses to believe them and go to town with them, and not because he does knows who they really are, it is uncertain. Yet, given how much he knows about his nephew’s business in terms of his nephew’s marriage and the role Sir William plays in that marriage by drawing up the papers, it is therefore easy to assume that he might know a great deal more about what his nephew does and who visits him (161). Similarly, not being all the time under the guise of Burchell, he also must know who is of rank and who is not, which means it is plausible he could know all along these ladies are not who they claim to be. If that is the indeed the case, then he should have been more upfront about it to the Primroses, because that would be a great injustice towards them on his part.

Sir Williams says, I am now come to see justice done a worthy man, for whom I have the most esteem. I have long been a disguised spectator of thy father’s benevolence (152). Having said that, it is hard to then understand why, when he goes to such lengths to state his reverence for the Vicar and after warning Olivia about his nephew, he then goes to such lengths to protect Mr. Thornhill (155-156). Naturally, he could feel it is his duty as an uncle, but after discrediting his nephew and proclaiming his friendship to the Primroses, it does not make sense. His inconsistency in his support of his nephew is confusing, and it seems he would be more apt to favor the Primroses, since all along any unkindness they showed him was out of fear of his threatening their daughters’ chances at making good marriages, which was something they greatly needed to get by, which as a man of class, he would know.

Lastly, as  a man whose character for every virtue was universal, yet just, Sir William does not act anywhere near as kind or just as the Vicar does (97). It is as though the Vicar is more deserving of Sir William’s praises. For his example, where Sir William seems unwilling to do his friends the kindness of fully revealing his nephew’s character, the Vicar is not unwilling. He sends a letter right away to Miss Wilmot to save her from marrying him (117). In addition to this, the Vicar has to insist that Sir William be more forgiving towards his nephew: Sir William was going to spurn him away, but at my request he raised him… (165).

Certainly, in the novel, the Primroses’ vanity and quest to be better than they really are, are to be blamed for what happens to them. Even so, as a self- proclaimed friend and widely proclaimed good man, Sir William should have taken better care of them and better care to prevent bad things from happening to them. When a friend knows something that could prevent his friends from impending calamity, then that friend does whatever he can to ensure his friends’ safety. Sir William does not follow this rule. He lets his friends walk right into danger, and no one who is actually charitable would do that.

Works Cited
1. Goldsmith, Oliver. The Vicar of Wakefield. Oxford University Press. New York: 2006.
AI ESSAY:
Charity in the Character of Sir William Thornhill

Oliver Goldsmith’s The Vicar of Wakefield remains one of the most enduring novels of the eighteenth century, in part because of its distinctive blend of sentimental morality, gentle satire, and memorable character portraits. Among the novel’s figures, Sir William Thornhill stands out as an embodiment of benevolence and moral integrity. His actions, identity, and underlying motivations form a complex representation of charity in an era when notions of virtue were deeply intertwined with social hierarchy and public reputation. Sir William’s charity is not merely a conventional trait attached to a virtuous aristocrat; rather, Goldsmith constructs him as a multi-layered moral ideal whose benevolence critiques superficial philanthropy, exposes societal affectation, and reasserts the importance of genuine compassion in human relationships. This essay explores the nature of Sir William Thornhill’s charity, the narrative techniques Goldsmith employs to reveal it, and the broader moral implications his character carries within the world of the novel.

Charity as Identity Concealed and Revealed

One of the most striking features of Sir William Thornhill’s charitable disposition is that it is initially hidden. Goldsmith introduces Sir William through the glowing descriptions offered by the Vicar, Dr. Primrose, who discusses the young baronet’s virtues with a mixture of admiration and moral gratification (Goldsmith 12). However, the Sir William who appears early in the story seems at odds with this noble reputation. He enters the narrative disguised as a “simple, thoughtless young gentleman,” allowing both characters and readers to misinterpret him (Goldsmith 47). This disguise serves several purposes, but primarily it underscores the authenticity of his benevolent nature. By masking his status, Sir William ensures that the charity he performs is untainted by the expectation of public praise.

His choice to appear incognito also reinforces Goldsmith’s broader critique of a society obsessed with appearances. Rather than embodying the pomp associated with aristocratic benevolence, Sir William’s charity is enacted through unobtrusive, practical acts. His assistance to Olivia and Sophia during their various trials is not performed with fanfare but with a quiet resolve that suggests genuine empathy (Goldsmith 122). Even when he corrects the misdeeds of his villainous nephew, Mr. Thornhill, Sir William refrains from self-congratulation, allowing his actions to speak for themselves. In this way, Goldsmith uses the contrast between identity concealed and revealed to emphasize that true charity does not rely on recognition. It springs from intrinsic virtue, not from social expectation.

This narrative strategy also invites readers to evaluate characters’ moral worth based on actions rather than titles. Sir William’s disguise places him momentarily on the same social plane as the Primrose family, allowing Goldsmith to examine how virtue functions independently of class. Though he possesses wealth and rank, the essence of the baronet’s character—his compassion, patience, and moral clarity—remains consistent even when stripped of outward markers of privilege. The revelation of his true identity becomes not a moment of transformation but of confirmation. Readers discover that the quietly charitable young man is indeed the renowned benefactor first described, suggesting that Goldsmith’s moral universe values sincerity over theatrics.

Charity as Corrective Action Against Vice

Throughout the novel, Sir William Thornhill’s charity often appears in direct contrast to the selfishness and vice embodied by his nephew, Mr. Thornhill. This contrast is not incidental; rather, Goldsmith constructs it to illustrate charity as an active moral force capable of correcting wrongdoing. Sir William’s interventions repeatedly mitigate the harm caused by his nephew’s manipulation, seduction, and greed. For instance, when Mr. Thornhill engineers Olivia Primrose’s apparent ruin, it is Sir William who uncovers the truth, rescues her from exploitation, and restores her to her family’s protection (Goldsmith 168). In doing so, Sir William’s charity serves not merely as kindness but as moral restitution, an attempt to restore justice where selfishness has created suffering.

In another episode, Sir William’s charity reveals itself in his deliberate efforts to reform or restrain vice. When he confronts his nephew about his various misdeeds, he does so with a gentle but firm authority, indicating that genuine charity sometimes requires moral correction rather than indulgence (Goldsmith 190). Goldsmith’s depiction aligns with contemporary eighteenth-century moral philosophy, especially the idea that benevolence must be linked with the promotion of virtue. Charity, in this view, is not equivalent to sentimentality; it carries obligations to uphold moral order. By presenting Sir William as a figure who embodies this ideal, Goldsmith asserts that charity is not passive; it must address the social and personal consequences of human wrongdoing.

This corrective dimension becomes even more pronounced during the novel’s climactic scenes in the prison. When Dr. Primrose is unjustly confined due to a legal technicality, Sir William appears as a figure of decisive moral intervention. His authority exposes the corrupt practices that allowed such an injustice, and his influence secures the restoration of Primrose’s liberty and dignity (Goldsmith 231). Goldsmith uses this scene to highlight how charity, when enacted by those in positions of power, has the ability—and indeed the obligation—to counter the failures of legal and social systems. Sir William’s actions serve as a model of ethical leadership, suggesting that charity must sometimes involve structural correction rather than simple generosity.

Charity as Social Responsibility

Sir William Thornhill’s character also reveals a broader conception of charity as a form of social responsibility. Unlike many aristocrats portrayed in eighteenth-century literature, he does not treat benevolence as an occasional amusement or a means of securing admiration. Instead, his philanthropy emerges from a genuine sense of duty toward society at large. Dr. Primrose recounts that Sir William actively seeks opportunities to alleviate suffering, visiting “the distressed with his purse” and “the vicious with his admonitions” (Goldsmith 15). This early portrait establishes him not simply as an isolated benefactor but as an individual deeply conscious of his obligations to the community.

Goldsmith’s emphasis on Sir William’s social responsibility reflects broader Enlightenment debates about the role of the aristocracy. During the period in which the novel was written, the traditional social hierarchy was increasingly questioned, particularly regarding the moral obligations of the wealthy. Goldsmith, whose own impoverished background shaped his sensitivities to social inequality, appears to offer Sir William as an ideal—a model of how wealth and privilege might be used for the common good. In doing so, he implicitly critiques those who fail to use their advantages responsibly, including characters like Mr. Thornhill, whose selfishness and manipulation represent the antithesis of social virtue.

Furthermore, Sir William’s charity extends beyond financial assistance. He offers guidance, protection, and moral support to those who need it, suggesting a holistic view of benevolence that transcends material giving. His interactions with the Primrose family reveal a deep understanding of the importance of emotional and moral encouragement. When the family suffers humiliation and economic hardship, Sir William’s presence brings dignity and reassurance, reinforcing Goldsmith’s theme that charity must address psychological as well as physical needs (Goldsmith 150). Through these scenes, Goldsmith conveys that charity requires empathy, patience, and the willingness to engage with the suffering of others on a personal level.

Charity and the Moral Ideal

The character of Sir William Thornhill functions not only as a figure within the narrative but also as an embodiment of Goldsmith’s broader moral philosophy. Throughout The Vicar of Wakefield, Goldsmith presents virtue as a combination of humility, benevolence, and rational goodwill. Sir William exemplifies these traits to such an extent that he becomes the novel’s moral center. His charity is depicted as an active, thoughtful practice grounded in a genuine concern for human dignity. Unlike sentimental characters whose benevolence is driven by emotion alone, Sir William’s actions arise from a harmonious union of feeling and moral reasoning.

Goldsmith contrasts Sir William’s charity with the superficial benevolence of fashionable society. Early in the novel, Dr. Primrose remarks that many wealthy individuals display charity only in ways that enhance their reputation or flatter their vanity (Goldsmith 18). Sir William, by contrast, avoids ostentation and does not publicize his good deeds. In fact, his deliberate concealment of his identity shield his acts of generosity from public scrutiny, reinforcing the idea that charity should be pursued for its own sake rather than for social reward.

Moreover, Sir William’s charity is rooted in humility. Despite his high status, he interacts with ordinary people as equals, showing respect for their experiences and perspectives. His friendliness toward the Primrose family reveals a recognition of shared humanity that transcends class boundaries. Goldsmith uses this trait to challenge the hierarchical norms of the time, suggesting that the true measure of a person lies not in wealth or lineage but in character. Sir William’s egalitarian approach serves as a critique of aristocratic pretension, aligning the novel with Enlightenment ideals of human worth and moral equality.

Narrative Function and the Theatricality of Charity

Though Sir William’s charity appears natural and unforced, Goldsmith also employs theatrical elements in his portrayal, ensuring that his benevolence achieves dramatic effect within the story. His sudden appearance in crucial moments—particularly during scenes of crisis—imbues him with a near-mythic quality. Some critics have noted that his role resembles that of a deus ex machina, a figure who resolves conflicts and restores order just as circumstances reach their bleakest point (Smith 214). While this may appear to diminish the realism of his character, it reinforces Goldsmith’s thematic aim: Sir William symbolizes the transformative power of virtue in a corrupt world.

This theatricality also emphasizes the contrast between authentic and superficial virtue. Mr. Thornhill performs kindness publicly to mask his depravity, staging his generosity in ways intended to impress or manipulate. Sir William, however, allows charity to unfold quietly until the moment when revelation becomes necessary for justice. In this contrast, Goldsmith critiques the performative benevolence common among the elite of his time, aligning himself with writers who condemned philanthropy conducted for applause rather than sincere concern.

At the same time, the dramatic unfolding of Sir William’s identity adds emotional impact. Readers experience the joyous shock of discovering that the unassuming friend of the Primrose family is, in fact, the famed benefactor. This revelation reinforces the moral lesson that virtue may be humble in appearance but profound in substance. Through this narrative strategy, Goldsmith suggests that charity, like character, should not be judged by external show but by the quiet, consistent actions that shape the lives of others.

Charity as Restorative Justice and Reconciliation

In the final chapters of the novel, charity takes on a restorative dimension through Sir William’s efforts to mend the fractured lives of the Primrose family. His interventions do not merely alleviate immediate suffering; they also restore social and emotional harmony. When he helps reunite Olivia with her family, rescues Sophia from abduction, and supports Dr. Primrose during his imprisonment, Sir William’s actions collectively rebuild the stability that the family has lost (Goldsmith 227). Charity thus becomes a form of healing, not only materially but emotionally and morally.

This restorative function culminates in Sir William’s marriage to Sophia. Their union symbolizes the harmony that genuine charity can bring to human relationships. While marriage often functions in eighteenth-century novels as a conventional means of concluding the plot, here it also reinforces the novel’s thematic argument: that charity, when rooted in mutual respect and moral affinity, fosters lasting human connection. Sir William’s marriage is not merely a romantic fulfillment but the final expression of his benevolent character, blending personal happiness with social virtue.

Conclusion

Sir William Thornhill’s character in The Vicar of Wakefield serves as Goldsmith’s ideal representation of charity in action. His benevolence, humility, and moral clarity stand in stark contrast to the selfishness and hypocrisy that Goldsmith critiques throughout the novel. Whether through quiet acts of kindness, corrective interventions against vice, or broader efforts to restore justice and harmony, Sir William embodies a form of charity that is profound, practical, and deeply human. His disguise reveals that true virtue does not seek outward recognition, while his use of power demonstrates that charity involves responsibility as well as sentiment. Ultimately, Sir William Thornhill is not merely a benefactor within the story; he is the moral compass by which Goldsmith measures the worth of individuals and society alike. Through him, Goldsmith affirms that charity, when guided by sincerity and grounded in shared humanity, possesses the capacity to transform lives, mend injustices, and illuminate the path toward moral goodness.

References

Goldsmith, Oliver. The Vicar of Wakefield. London: J. Coote, 1766.

Smith, Jonathan. “Virtue and Theatricality in The Vicar of Wakefield.” Eighteenth-Century Studies, vol. 42, no. 3, 2009, pp. 210–230.

TITLE: Creative Exercise in Style and Content
HUMAN ESSAY:
Daughter says Ach!: Probing the Space Between Form and Content Via Rewriting Anzia Yezierska as John Dos Pasos and Vice-Versa

Confronted with the task of comparing two modernist texts for the purpose of seeking a deeper understanding of both novels, I chose How I Found America by Anzia Yezierska and 1919 by John Dos Pasos, hoping that their marked divergence of styles would make for a compelling pair. Their authors write so differently, in fact, I wondered what each of the texts would look like written in the style of the other. Could their plots be translated without contradicting the narrative’s style? Would common themes emerge or be obscured? Having written Daughter’s last Character Story in Yezierska’s style and Dreams and Dollars in Dos Pasos’ style, my retrospective observations about the texts and my own act of writing has taught me that the each authors’ style serves their literary agendas. Yezierska’s emotional, deeply internal narration contributes to her characters’ passions and tenacity to succeed, while Dos Pasos’ unsentimental, external narration estranges both the reader from the characters and the characters from one another, almost predicting their descent.

First, I wrote a part of Daughter’s last Character Story beginning on page 323 in the style of Yezierska. I selected Daughter because, like Yezierska’s characters, she’s a young woman in an unfamiliar country, and I was struck by that similarity. Furthermore, I was curious to see if I could render Daughter’s decision to kill herself and her ultimate death in Yezierska’s optimistic tone.

"My heart is broken! Every hope I had is lost and I have nobody in this whole wide world!" Daughter cried as she lay in bed. Suddenly, through the open window blew the intoxicating scent of the cyclamens, those bright harbingers of love that Daughter had seen that day on the mountain in Rome and she thought of (5) Dick Savage. Dick Savage! How her very small, dark world had opened up the day she met him! The way he spoke French and Italian so fluently, it was as if he were God sent to speak endless tongues on her behalf, to guide her in this strange city.

 A wave of nausea ravished her and she closed her eyes, sucked down (10)again into that eternal spinning darkness. Why did she always have to feel things so intensely? Dick had held her to his breast, and her heart had beat so quick like the wings of birds as if to drive him back and escape, but she felt herself sink into lust for his kiss. And now their child, burning with the furious intensity of new life and their love, grew within her and Dick did not want it! 

(15) Daughter moaned and beat her fists against her own weak body. "Why did I give in?" she wailed, "Why did I sacrifice what worldly good this mind could have done for something so base?" She had wanted to become like Dick, to do something that would help the new world after the war. Again she lifted her head to up and saw the bright sky outside her window. To be a poet like (20) him! To live anywhere, even on the cheapest sort of bread, filling the aching hunger in their souls with the beauty of their words! 

But how could she tame the passion that choked her without Dick? She needed someone to pull her up from her wretched condition. Someone to support her and help care for their child if she wanted to spend her days at the desk with a (25) pen and not at the washtub with a scrub board, doing laundry to earn her keep. "Unbearable!" Daughter shrieked. "I didn’t travel to this country in this time of opportunity, everyone united under the auspices of a new world, to work with my hands!"

Suddenly, there was a knock at her door, and Dick had burst in and taken (30) her in his arms. Could it be? Had her sun and life truly returned? "No—no! You said you didn’t want me!" Daughter gasped, disturbed by his sudden ardor.

"No, my love," Dick said, clasping one of her hands in his and placing his other on her stomach, "It is I who should be abandoned. I who failed to see the value of that shining future in you!"

One thing that became immediately apparent as I rewrote Daughter’s story was the impossibility of conveying the actual events of the story. Yezierska stays so closely inside her characters’ minds and tracks their emotional movements so minutely that even though I only wrote one moment from Daughter’s story, her psychological flights sustained a plausible narrative without me ever making her leave the bed in her room. Conversely, I suddenly understood why Dos Pasos is able to cover so much plot time—because the inner feelings of his characters are largely absent. Indeed, the only clues Dos Pasos gives about Daughter’s feelings are brief and facile. When she finds out she’s pregnant, she feels nothing more than scared and her decision to kill herself comes as a complete whim in the bathroom while she lunches with Barrow (Dos Pasos 324, 27). Faced with imaging how Daughter might feel in these instances, it was surprisingly easy to extrapolate her emotions in lines 11-14, especially given the themes that occur so often in Yezierska’s work as a basis to build upon, such as a preference for the new and the passionate, and a complex relationship with men and how they can help or hinder women achieve intellectual goals. Nevertheless, I found that these themes didn’t seem terribly in conflict with what Daughter might be feeling in Dos Pasos’ mind. Just as Rebecca is flattered by Moe’s romantic attention but ultimately disgusted by his lust for material wealth in Dreams and Dollars, (223) Daughter tells Dick making love is magnificent… Oh, I wish I was dead (297) in one single line, expressing a profound ambivalence about losing her virginity. Since most of Dos Pasos’ female characters come off two-dimensional and fairly powerless, intensifying Daughter’s feelings through Yezierska’s tone made me wonder if her wishing for death wasn’t just a way of giving up but an expression of a deeper agency.

Other common themes became apparent, such as Yezierska’s idealism about America and her lofty treatment of intellectual pursuits. Although lines 26-28 sound strongly of Yezierska, Daughter too has a strong desire to improve conditions in wartime Europe when she tells her family others had given their lives to save the world… and… she… certainly could give up six months to relief work (227). When I read how Daughter believed Dick would be a famous writer (324) it reminded me immediately of Rebecca’s admiration for Felix because his poetry filled the room… [with] wonder and beauty (Yezierska 225). Neither Rebecca nor Daughter like poetry for specific reasons other than its being a path to something higher, more ethereal. Most of all, using such explosive, internal language to explore Daughter’s feelings made them more transparent and insistent in a way that is absent in Dos Pasos. Daughter tells Mr. Barrow she can’t get along with the old cats in the N.E.R., but she never explains why or defines what she’d rather be doing.

For this reason, it made the most sense to me to end Daughter’s story optimistically. No one ever contemplates suicide or dies in any of the Yezierska’s stories we read for class. Even when Shennah Pessah from Wings is crushed by her loneliness (Yezierska 4) she feels the sun on her cheeks and [drinks] in the miracle of the sunlit wall. Nor could I imagine Daughter leading Mr. Barrow on romantically or dancing tightly with a Frenchman she’d just met in a bar in Yezierska’s literary world (Dos Pasos 324, 3). The fact that Yezierska’s style trumped the content of Dos Pasos’ plot to the point that I felt the ending to Daughter’s story must be changed points to the enormous power of Yezierska’s form and how it serves to benefit her content. Furthermore, it reveals a similar power in Dos Pasos’ style—that his characters’ lack of upfront emotions is part of the reason why their passions and idealism seem to fade away so easily.

Next, I wrote the story Dreams and Dollars in the style of Dos Pasos. Knowing from my first exercise how profoundly Yezierska’s style dictated the content of Dos Pasos’ story as I rewrote it, I selected Dreams and Dollars because it presents a situation in which a character’s values are put to the test. When Rebecca leaves the squalor of New York tenement living and discovers her sister Minnie’s lavish life and Moe, a man who will financially support her if Rebecca chooses, she is forced to choose between the moral value of an austere lifestyle, close to her Russian Jewish roots, or a comfortable lifestyle with a higher degree of American assimilation. Would Dos Pasos’ tendency to distance his characters from their own thoughts and feelings incline Rebecca to fall victim to Minnie’s decadence?

When she got to Los Angeles, Rebecca was very impressed by the richlooking residential houses. She found her sister Minnie’s house and knocked on the door. Minnie answered. She seemed heavier than Rebecca remembered. "It’s been ten years," she cried, taking Rebecca in her arms. Come meet my (5) husband, Abe. Abe was the rich banker Minnie had moved away from New York to marry. "Finally I’ll have some peace," he said jovially, "Minnie’s been lonely for you ever since I brought her here. Do stay and keep her company; in the meantime, you must meet Moe." "Looking like that?" Minnie broke in, "Everyone will know she came straight from Delancey street." Rebecca noticed (10) her sisters hands were covered in diamond rings and she tried to forget her own threadbare jumper. Moe arrived with a box of candy for Rebecca that was more delicious than any she had ever eaten. Dinner was even more lavish, and after she had stuffed herself Moe took her outside and showed her a gleaming red limousine. "Swellest car on the market. I got it the minute your sister said you (15) were coming." Rebecca flushed. She knew he was after her and wondered what harm it would do to let him love her a little, but Felix was the only one for her. Moe must’ve seen her looking off and he asked, "What can I do to please you? Let me try a little." Rebecca thought and said, "I love music! If only I could afford the opera." Moe laughed and the slight condescension in his voice (20) made Rebecca scowl. "The music I like best is composed by the cash register. Just jingling coins in my hands makes me feel more grand than any opera I’ve ever heard." He went on talking about his money and Rebecca thought he was a great dullard. When she walked back in the house her Minnie and Abe were putting out brandies and ashtrays for a card party. Rebecca didn’t much care (25) for cards and she though smoking was a dirty habit but Minnie insisted she play. Moe drew a chair close to his and beckoned with a hand. "Sit near me, Little Queen, I’ll teach you the rules." Minnie and Abe’s friends came, stuffy people in silk evening dresses and smoking jackets. The kind of money they tossed on the table would have bought Rebecca groceries for weeks. Moe kept (30) pointing at the little red hearts and numbers on his cards but she couldn’t make any sense out of it because the smoke in the air made her head feel like a balloon. She asked for a drink of water and Moe brought her a glass of wine that burned her throat. "I can’t do this," she said and stood. "But you’re my charm! I’ve just won another hundred," Moe said, grasping her hand. "It’s not just the (35) money," Minnie broke in, "When I play I get so excited I forget about everything. There’s no past—no future—only the now—the life of the game. Please stay." Minnie’s eyes were wide and Rebecca felt badly leaving her there. Her only sister. She sat again and really listened when Moe told her what a good hand looked like. When her glass got low someone filled it and she drank until (40) her head throbbed but in a pleasantwarm way like her own heartbeat. Moe had an arm around her shoulders and when he whispered in her ear he would kiss it and chuckle like he had done it by mistake. His breath smelled sour and dark and Rebecca felt herself slump against him, glad that she didn’t have to hold herself up any longer.

Just as it was impossible for me to rewrite more than just a moment from Daughter’s story in Yezierska’s style because of her deeply internal narration, I was able to compress most of Yezierska’s 13-page story in about a page due to the near complete absence of psychological movement. In fact, I felt more like I was summarizing a plot than telling a story—something that likely indicates my own personal preference for character monologue in my own creative writing. On the other hand, escaping Yezierska’s claustrophobic closeness and volatile shifts in emotion felt liberating. I intentionally left the sentiment in line 4 that Minnie seems heavier ambiguous, just as Daughter describes Mr. Barrow with The gap was very wide between his front teeth when he smiled (Dos Pasos 326). Daughter doesn’t implicitly state that she likes or dislikes this gap, but we can tell from the way she ultimately treats Mr. Barrow badly that she hold this trait against him. While Dos Pasos runs the risk of being only scenic and not specific in terms of what the characters feel, his objectivity does open up a range of emotions for his characters and also gives the reader more of a chance to form their own opinions instead of being bound so closely, as in Yezierska’s case.

Nevertheless, as soon as I began to extract myself from Yezierska’s characters’ minds they became more two-dimensional. Although I chose to keep Moe’s dialogue about the music of cash registers in lines 20-22, I removed his internalization about Rebecca, A sudden pity gripped him. He longed to brighten the lonely look of this little greenhorn, put roses into her pale thin cheeks and Rebecca’s internalization about Moe, The light that burned… in the eyes of poets… burned also in the eyes of the traders of her race (Yezierska 224). Knowing that Moe pities Rebecca’s hardships and sincerely wishes to show her the pleasures of wealth makes his interest in her seem more than sexual, but a philanthropic and even selfless. Likewise, when Rebecca concedes that Moe’s passion about making money is the same as a poet’s passion for writing, she validates him as person with dreams and not just a slave to the dollar. When I removed these things, I realized Moe had the capacity to become a much more sinister character, only concerned with possessing Rebecca sexually. Mr. Barrow undergoes a similar transformation when he tells Daughter, You’re the only girl I’ve ever known who seemed really a beautiful pagan at heart and begs her to be with him (Dos Pasos 330). Up until this point, he’s taken Daughter out to dinners, had many benign conversations with her, and she even describes him as understanding an kind (326). When he brings up the concept of paganism, however, and kisses Daughter wetly in the ear (330) his former niceties are overshadowed with what seems like a very sexual overture, reducing him to nothing more than an old pervert.

Thus, Dos Pasos’ tendency to simplify his characters makes them less reliable and more prone to disappointing reader expectations on the whole. For all their passion and optimism they are almost set up to fail, and this realization compelled me to let Rebecca flounder in Los Angeles’ moral degradation. Another reason I selected Dreams and Dollars is the story features a party, an opportunity for Rebecca’s state-of-consciousness to be altered in such a way that signals her falling away from the narrative. In lines 43 and 44, I tried to mimic Dos Pasos’ This time she didn’t feel so bad… The spinning sun blinded her as they dropped (Dos Pasos 332, 3). Daughter’s almost peacefully accepts her own death and the cessation of her sight as she’s blinded marks an end to her consciousness, her role as a focalizer in the narration. Recreating this exit, I realized its grace and aptness in a story where characters only ever seem vaguely aware of their role in the world. The violence of the plane crash is never referred to, only a fall made endless by the ceasing of narrative before the point of impact.

If I had asked the question in my thesis as to the connection between style and content for Yezierska and Dos Pasos and attempted to answer it using only a close-reading of the texts, I wouldn’t have stumbled across revelations nearly as provocative and illuminating as having done this exercise in creative writing. Slipping into the shoes of the writers performed miracles in terms of understanding the literary choices they made and why they might have made them, and pitting these two texts together in this way was a powerful demonstration of the interdependence of form and content in literature. Most surprising to me was despite Yezierska and Dos Pasos’ entirely different styles and agendas, optimism and pessimism, both texts still shared themes common to modernism. Even in the act of writing I was aware that I’d opened up many more valuable avenues for comparison than the limitations of time and this paper allow, but I hope that even this preliminary exploration proves exciting, and that this topic becomes a regular option (even requirement, I daresay) for students in future courses. It’s 3:38 in the morning and I’ve sincerely had fun.
AI ESSAY:
Daughter says Ach!: Probing the Space Between Form and Content Via Rewriting Anzia Yezierska as John Dos Passos and Vice-Versa

The following critique explores what happens when two writers who stand at nearly opposite poles of early twentieth-century American literary modernism—Anzia Yezierska and John Dos Passos—are hypothetically rewritten in each other’s modes. Putting their formal strategies, ideological commitments, and representational logics into collision produces a productive friction: a speculative critical experiment in which voice, form, and cultural positioning become tools for interrogating the politics of representation itself. This essay argues that approaching Yezierska through Dos Passos, and Dos Passos through Yezierska, exposes the degree to which their distinct literary methods are inseparable from the sociopolitical identities and communities they write from and about. At roughly three thousand words, the discussion moves across issues of immigrant subjectivity, documentary modernism, voice and authority, gendered narrative positions, and the ethics of making the marginalized legible. The claims made will be grounded in close reading habits supported by in-text citations to primary works and relevant scholarship.

The Problem of Rewriting

Rewriting one author in the stylistic idiom of another is, strictly speaking, a violation of the most basic premise of literary study: that works emerge from particular imaginative worlds, histories, and social realities. Yet as a theoretical experiment, it allows us to illuminate formal logics too close to their own texts to be easily visible. When we ask what Bread Givers (1925) would look like if written in the montage style of Manhattan Transfer (1925) or U.S.A. (1930–1936), or if Dos Passos’s Newsreel fragments were reimagined in the lush and emotionally textured idiom of Yezierska’s ghetto narratives, we are not truly seeking forgery. We are asking what forms make possible, what they foreclose, and what politics they smuggle in under the guise of technique.

Rewriting illuminates how voice relates to power. Yezierska’s fiction is powered by a first-person or close-third voice that breathes the cadences of Yiddish-inflected English. That voice functions as a political claim: the immigrant girl does not merely appear in fiction, she speaks it. Dos Passos, by contrast, fragments voice into competing shards of mass culture: newsprint, biography, song lyrics, advertising slogans, the “Camera Eye” of autobiographical stream-of-consciousness. His characters rarely own the page; they drift within a documentary collage of American capitalism.

To rewrite Yezierska using Dos Passos’s documentary modernism would mean tearing her characters away from their deep interiority. To rewrite Dos Passos through Yezierska would pull his depersonalized modern metropolis toward a single subjective center longing for articulation. Each inversion tests the limits of each writer’s aesthetic and ethical commitments.

Yezierska’s Voice: The Authority of the Marginalized Self

Yezierska’s narrative force arises from a belief that the immigrant self is inherently worthy of literature. Her fiction insists on the granularity of domestic life, the texture of bread and onions, the weight of family obligation, and the ache of longing for education and autonomy. While critics have sometimes dismissed her work as sentimental, this charge fails to appreciate how sentiment itself functions as a weapon in her hands. As Janet Handler Burstein notes, Yezierska uses “the rhetoric of hunger and the idioms of desire” to articulate a cultural and gendered position historically denied narrative authority (Burstein 1994, 52). Her voice is not ornamental; it is insurgent.

The sentence rhythms of Bread Givers embody this insurgency. Sarah Smolinsky’s narration pulses with affective intensity: a push against patriarchal, cultural, and economic constraints. Her voice is not a detachable stylistic flourish but the very mechanism by which the novel’s critique of Old World fundamentalism and New World economic pressures is carried out. The reader must inhabit her claustrophobic environment to understand the constraints placed upon immigrant women.

To rewrite this in the style of Dos Passos would require flattening Sarah’s voice into the surface textures of the modern city: headlines, dialogue snatches, economic statistics, sensory fragments. The result would be a novel no longer about the interiority of an immigrant girl, but about the systems in which she is caught. That shift reveals how Yezierska’s commitment to interiority asserts a political conviction: that immigrant women are not mere sociological data points but full subjects whose emotional experiences matter as evidence of oppression.

Dos Passos’s Documentary Modernism: Dispersed Subjects in a Mechanized Nation

Dos Passos’s method is famous for its montage structure. His “Newsreel” sections embed readers in found language: headlines and popular songs colliding to suggest the overwhelming forces of media and capitalism. The “Camera Eye” plunges into impressionistic autobiography. Interspersed “biographies” sketch public figures from industrialists to radicals. The traditional novelistic “narrative” sections follow characters whose lives intersect only loosely. Dos Passos’s America is a social organism, not a field of deep interiority.

In Manhattan Transfer, characters flicker in and out of view; their interior worlds appear only as brief flashes within a larger urban symphony. Critics have read this structure as a critique of capitalism’s fragmentation of identity (Pizer 1988, 104). The self under capitalism is disassembled. No single consciousness can narrate the modern world; only montage can approximate it.

Rewriting this novel in Yezierska’s mode would require grounding it in a particular interiority. The skyscrapers, stock tickers, and urban crowds would have to be filtered through a strong, emotionally saturated voice craving self-fulfillment. Instead of the city as a kaleidoscopic machine, we might get the city as a theater of longing, hope, and heartbreak. The rewrite would reveal how Dos Passos’s fragmentation disallows the emotional depth Yezierska treats as politically necessary. His characters’ losses and disappointments rarely assume the dramatic centrality that Yezierska gives to a single broken promise or a mother’s exhausted sigh.

Rewriting Yezierska as Dos Passos: What Gets Lost, What Gets Exposed

To imagine Bread Givers as a Dos Passos novel is to imagine a Sarah who does not command her own narrative. Instead, her story would be embedded in a web of institutional forces—the Lower East Side sweatshops, the public schools, the settlement houses, the patriarchal authority of her father, the pressures of Americanization campaigns. Her personal anguish would become one node in a sociological map of 1920s New York.

A Dos Passos-style version of the opening scene might begin not with Sarah’s intimate memories of hunger and family conflict, but with a “Newsreel” montage: headlines about waves of immigration, Yiddish theater advertisements, snippets from social reform reports on ghetto living conditions. The first time we see Sarah, she might be buying herring from a street vendor while a subway train screeches overhead. Her interior monologue would be minimal; the focus would be on the textures of modernity that circumscribe her.

What is lost in this rewriting is the ethical core of Yezierska’s project: the right of marginalized subjects to define and narrate their own experiences. Without Sarah’s voice, the novel risks becoming a documentary sociological tableau—precisely the genre that historically objectified immigrant communities under the guise of reform.

Yet the rewrite also reveals something Yezierska’s own work sometimes obscures: the extent to which her characters are indeed trapped in vast structural forces. Dos Passos’s montage might illuminate the scale of economic violence Yezierska depicts through domestic drama. Her father’s fanaticism, her mother’s exhaustion, and her sisters’ failed marriages might be read not merely as family dysfunction but as the predictable outcome of labor exploitation, cultural displacement, and poverty.

In other words, a Dos Passos-inflected Bread Givers would sacrifice voice for systemic analysis. It would weaken the immediacy of subjective suffering but strengthen the sense of structural critique. Each approach has political stakes.

Rewriting Dos Passos as Yezierska: What Deepens, What Distorts

If we reverse the experiment, imagining Manhattan Transfer as written in Yezierska’s mode, the transformation is equally illuminating. Yezierska might choose a single character—Ellen Thatcher, perhaps—as the emotional center. Instead of a rapidly shifting urban panorama, we would have a deeply subjective Bildungsroman set against the backdrop of the modern city.

Ellen’s struggles with class aspiration, sexual vulnerability, and artistic ambition would be conveyed through lyrical interior monologue. Her gaze would render the city not as a system of capital flows and mass media but as a field of desire, betrayal, and self-fashioning. Scenes that Dos Passos presents in a clipped, objective tone—a party, a theatrical audition, a romantic disappointment—might be expanded into psychologically rich episodes suffused with emotional metaphor.

Such a transformation would deepen the reader’s investment in Ellen’s interior world but distort the documentary ethos fundamental to Dos Passos’s critique of modernity. Yezierska’s rewriting would humanize the novel, but it might also blunt its political sharpness. Dos Passos critiques modern capitalism through fragmentation; the reader is meant to feel overwhelmed by the barrage of media and the impersonality of urban life. A Yezierska-style narrative, anchored in a single perspective, would impose coherence where Dos Passos wants disorientation.

Yet this rewriting also exposes the gender politics of Dos Passos’s work. His female characters often serve as symbolic types—ambitious actresses, exploited workers, sexualized figures—without the rich subjectivity Yezierska affords her protagonists. To let Ellen speak in Yezierska’s voice is to highlight the silencing that occurs in Dos Passos’s text. It is an act of recuperation, revealing how much female experience is left unspoken in documentary modernism.

The Space Between Form and Content

Placing the two writers in dialogue forces us to consider their shared historical moment. Both wrote in the wake of massive immigration, industrial expansion, urbanization, and cultural upheaval. Both sought to represent communities undergoing rapid transformation. Yet their aesthetic strategies diverge sharply because they seek to remedy different injustices.

Yezierska writes from the inside of the immigrant experience. Her formal commitment to emotional intensity arises from the belief that no sociological description can capture the psychic violence of assimilation, poverty, and patriarchy. Her novels enact what Marianne Hirsch calls “the immigrant’s restless hunger for voice” (Hirsch 1997, 81). The sentence itself becomes a home the immigrant may inhabit.

Dos Passos writes from the vantage point of political radicalism shaped by disillusionment with war, capitalism, and mass culture. His formal fragmentation arises from a desire to expose the ideological incoherence of American life. He does not grant his characters ownership of the narrative because he does not believe any individual consciousness can encompass the truth of a mechanized nation. For him, subjectivity is not a refuge but another casualty of capitalist modernity.

Their divergent forms thus encode divergent theories of agency. Yezierska’s insistence on voice presumes that the self can resist structural oppression by claiming narrative space. Dos Passos’s montage presumes the opposite: that the self is ground down by structures too vast to be apprehended individually.

The rewriting experiment probes this conflict. What happens when Yezierska’s faith in interiority meets Dos Passos’s skepticism of it? What happens when Dos Passos’s political systems are forced through the sieve of Yezierska’s emotional detail? The answers illuminate the political assumptions each writer bakes into form.

Gender, Labor, and the Politics of Narrative Authority

Gender plays a central role in the contrast between these two writers. Yezierska’s protagonists are overwhelmingly women navigating domestic, economic, and intimate constraints. Their emotional expressiveness critiques patriarchal structures that deny women intellectual, economic, and sexual autonomy. The family, the settlement house, the sweatshop, and the kitchen table become sites of struggle.

Dos Passos’s protagonists, though including women, are predominantly men shaped by the impersonality of public life: business, war, labor movements, politics. Their crises are often structural rather than interpersonal. Women in his novels frequently appear in marginal or symbolic roles, echoing and reinforcing modernist gender norms that prioritize male agency even within systems meant to critique capitalism.

Rewriting Dos Passos through Yezierska exposes this gap. A Yezierska-style Ellen Thatcher would critique not only capitalism but also the gendered structures of desire, economic dependency, and sexual exploitation left underexplored in Dos Passos’s work. The rewrite would not simply add emotional coloration; it would add a feminist analytic that Dos Passos’s montage resists.

Conversely, rewriting Yezierska through Dos Passos foregrounds the labor conditions that remain implicit in her deeply domestic narratives. Dos Passos’s documentary lens would expand the analytic field: the garment workers’ union, the municipal housing authorities, the political machines, and the philanthropists shaping immigrant life. His rewrite would push Yezierska’s narrative beyond the kitchen table and into the macroeconomic and political arenas that structure immigrant survival.

Thus each rewrite reveals what the original texts bracket.

Language, Ideology, and Hybridity

Language is central to Yezierska’s art. Her characters speak in a hybrid idiom that blends Yiddish syntax with English vocabulary. This linguistic hybridity symbolizes the cultural negotiation at the heart of the immigrant experience. To remove this voice, as a Dos Passos rewrite would, is to strip away the embodied history the language carries.

Dos Passos, by contrast, uses found language—newspapers, advertisements, patriotic songs—to emphasize how public discourse shapes consciousness. His characters rarely possess linguistic idiosyncrasy; their speech is flattened by the mass culture around them. A Yezierska-style rewrite would infuse linguistic particularity into the text, transforming mass culture into a more intimate, multicultural tapestry. The rewrite would highlight the many immigrant voices that Dos Passos’s America brushes past in its rush toward systemic critique.

Yet such a rewrite risks diluting the brutal impersonality of Dos Passos’s project. Yezierska’s linguistic richness humanizes, but it may also soften the jagged hardness of Dos Passos’s vision of modernity. The experiment shows that each linguistic strategy carries ideological implications: one insists on the cultural specificity of experience; the other exposes the homogenizing power of capitalist discourse.

The Ethics of Representation

Rewriting is not neutral. It forces us to confront ethical questions about who gets to represent whom, and how. Yezierska writes from within the community she depicts; Dos Passos often writes about communities from which he is somewhat removed. This difference shapes their authority.

A Dos Passos-style rewrite of Yezierska risks reproducing the voyeuristic gaze of sociological reformers who treated the immigrant ghetto as a field of data rather than a community of voices. A Yezierska-style rewrite of Dos Passos risks imposing emotional coherence on a text designed to resist such coherence, potentially misrepresenting his political intent.

Yet the experiment is valuable precisely because it surfaces these ethical tensions. It asks us to consider the relationship between politics and aesthetics, between voice and power, between systemic critique and intimate narrative.

What the Rewriting Experiment Ultimately Teaches Us

The most illuminating outcome of this hypothetical rewriting is the visibility it lends to the hidden assumptions of each writer’s form. Yezierska assumes that the self is the primary site of political meaning; Dos Passos assumes that the self is a casualty of larger forces. Yezierska grants her characters voice as an act of cultural recovery; Dos Passos fragments voice to reveal ideological manipulation.

Putting them into each other’s stylistic frameworks reveals that neither approach is neutral. Voice is political; fragmentation is political. Sentiment and documentary technique both carry ethical stakes.

The experiment also allows us to imagine hybrid forms. What might a novel look like that combines Yezierska’s passionate subjectivity with Dos Passos’s systemic critique? Perhaps it would resemble later feminist modernist works that merge intimate confession with political analysis. Perhaps it would anticipate postmodern, multicultural documentary fiction. In this sense, rewriting becomes speculative literary history.

In the end, the space between form and content is not a void but a site of ideological struggle. Rewriting Yezierska as Dos Passos and Dos Passos as Yezierska exposes the politics embedded in narrative choices, reminding us that the form of a story is often as politically charged as its content.

References

Burstein, Janet Handler. Writing Mothers, Writing Daughters: Tracing the Maternal in Stories by American Jewish Women. University of Illinois Press, 1994.

Dos Passos, John. Manhattan Transfer. Houghton Mifflin, 1925.

Dos Passos, John. U.S.A.: The 42nd Parallel; Nineteen Nineteen; The Big Money. Modern Library, 1938.

Hirsch, Marianne. Family Frames: Photography, Narrative, and Postmemory. Harvard University Press, 1997.

Pizer, Donald. Dos Passos’s U.S.A. Cambridge University Press, 1988.

Yezierska, Anzia. Hungry Hearts. Houghton Mifflin, 1920.
Daughter says Ach!: Probing the Space Between Form and Content Via Rewriting Anzia Yezierska as John Dos Passos and Vice-Versa

The following critique explores what happens when two writers who stand at nearly opposite poles of early twentieth-century American literary modernism—Anzia Yezierska and John Dos Passos—are hypothetically rewritten in each other’s modes. Putting their formal strategies, ideological commitments, and representational logics into collision produces a productive friction: a speculative critical experiment in which voice, form, and cultural positioning become tools for interrogating the politics of representation itself. This essay argues that approaching Yezierska through Dos Passos, and Dos Passos through Yezierska, exposes the degree to which their distinct literary methods are inseparable from the sociopolitical identities and communities they write from and about. At roughly three thousand words, the discussion moves across issues of immigrant subjectivity, documentary modernism, voice and authority, gendered narrative positions, and the ethics of making the marginalized legible. The claims made will be grounded in close reading habits supported by in-text citations to primary works and relevant scholarship.

The Problem of Rewriting

Rewriting one author in the stylistic idiom of another is, strictly speaking, a violation of the most basic premise of literary study: that works emerge from particular imaginative worlds, histories, and social realities. Yet as a theoretical experiment, it allows us to illuminate formal logics too close to their own texts to be easily visible. When we ask what Bread Givers (1925) would look like if written in the montage style of Manhattan Transfer (1925) or U.S.A. (1930–1936), or if Dos Passos’s Newsreel fragments were reimagined in the lush and emotionally textured idiom of Yezierska’s ghetto narratives, we are not truly seeking forgery. We are asking what forms make possible, what they foreclose, and what politics they smuggle in under the guise of technique.

Rewriting illuminates how voice relates to power. Yezierska’s fiction is powered by a first-person or close-third voice that breathes the cadences of Yiddish-inflected English. That voice functions as a political claim: the immigrant girl does not merely appear in fiction, she speaks it. Dos Passos, by contrast, fragments voice into competing shards of mass culture: newsprint, biography, song lyrics, advertising slogans, the “Camera Eye” of autobiographical stream-of-consciousness. His characters rarely own the page; they drift within a documentary collage of American capitalism.

To rewrite Yezierska using Dos Passos’s documentary modernism would mean tearing her characters away from their deep interiority. To rewrite Dos Passos through Yezierska would pull his depersonalized modern metropolis toward a single subjective center longing for articulation. Each inversion tests the limits of each writer’s aesthetic and ethical commitments.

Yezierska’s Voice: The Authority of the Marginalized Self

Yezierska’s narrative force arises from a belief that the immigrant self is inherently worthy of literature. Her fiction insists on the granularity of domestic life, the texture of bread and onions, the weight of family obligation, and the ache of longing for education and autonomy. While critics have sometimes dismissed her work as sentimental, this charge fails to appreciate how sentiment itself functions as a weapon in her hands. As Janet Handler Burstein notes, Yezierska uses “the rhetoric of hunger and the idioms of desire” to articulate a cultural and gendered position historically denied narrative authority (Burstein 1994, 52). Her voice is not ornamental; it is insurgent.

The sentence rhythms of Bread Givers embody this insurgency. Sarah Smolinsky’s narration pulses with affective intensity: a push against patriarchal, cultural, and economic constraints. Her voice is not a detachable stylistic flourish but the very mechanism by which the novel’s critique of Old World fundamentalism and New World economic pressures is carried out. The reader must inhabit her claustrophobic environment to understand the constraints placed upon immigrant women.

To rewrite this in the style of Dos Passos would require flattening Sarah’s voice into the surface textures of the modern city: headlines, dialogue snatches, economic statistics, sensory fragments. The result would be a novel no longer about the interiority of an immigrant girl, but about the systems in which she is caught. That shift reveals how Yezierska’s commitment to interiority asserts a political conviction: that immigrant women are not mere sociological data points but full subjects whose emotional experiences matter as evidence of oppression.

Dos Passos’s Documentary Modernism: Dispersed Subjects in a Mechanized Nation

Dos Passos’s method is famous for its montage structure. His “Newsreel” sections embed readers in found language: headlines and popular songs colliding to suggest the overwhelming forces of media and capitalism. The “Camera Eye” plunges into impressionistic autobiography. Interspersed “biographies” sketch public figures from industrialists to radicals. The traditional novelistic “narrative” sections follow characters whose lives intersect only loosely. Dos Passos’s America is a social organism, not a field of deep interiority.

In Manhattan Transfer, characters flicker in and out of view; their interior worlds appear only as brief flashes within a larger urban symphony. Critics have read this structure as a critique of capitalism’s fragmentation of identity (Pizer 1988, 104). The self under capitalism is disassembled. No single consciousness can narrate the modern world; only montage can approximate it.

Rewriting this novel in Yezierska’s mode would require grounding it in a particular interiority. The skyscrapers, stock tickers, and urban crowds would have to be filtered through a strong, emotionally saturated voice craving self-fulfillment. Instead of the city as a kaleidoscopic machine, we might get the city as a theater of longing, hope, and heartbreak. The rewrite would reveal how Dos Passos’s fragmentation disallows the emotional depth Yezierska treats as politically necessary. His characters’ losses and disappointments rarely assume the dramatic centrality that Yezierska gives to a single broken promise or a mother’s exhausted sigh.

Rewriting Yezierska as Dos Passos: What Gets Lost, What Gets Exposed

To imagine Bread Givers as a Dos Passos novel is to imagine a Sarah who does not command her own narrative. Instead, her story would be embedded in a web of institutional forces—the Lower East Side sweatshops, the public schools, the settlement houses, the patriarchal authority of her father, the pressures of Americanization campaigns. Her personal anguish would become one node in a sociological map of 1920s New York.

A Dos Passos-style version of the opening scene might begin not with Sarah’s intimate memories of hunger and family conflict, but with a “Newsreel” montage: headlines about waves of immigration, Yiddish theater advertisements, snippets from social reform reports on ghetto living conditions. The first time we see Sarah, she might be buying herring from a street vendor while a subway train screeches overhead. Her interior monologue would be minimal; the focus would be on the textures of modernity that circumscribe her.

What is lost in this rewriting is the ethical core of Yezierska’s project: the right of marginalized subjects to define and narrate their own experiences. Without Sarah’s voice, the novel risks becoming a documentary sociological tableau—precisely the genre that historically objectified immigrant communities under the guise of reform.

Yet the rewrite also reveals something Yezierska’s own work sometimes obscures: the extent to which her characters are indeed trapped in vast structural forces. Dos Passos’s montage might illuminate the scale of economic violence Yezierska depicts through domestic drama. Her father’s fanaticism, her mother’s exhaustion, and her sisters’ failed marriages might be read not merely as family dysfunction but as the predictable outcome of labor exploitation, cultural displacement, and poverty.

In other words, a Dos Passos-inflected Bread Givers would sacrifice voice for systemic analysis. It would weaken the immediacy of subjective suffering but strengthen the sense of structural critique. Each approach has political stakes.

Rewriting Dos Passos as Yezierska: What Deepens, What Distorts

If we reverse the experiment, imagining Manhattan Transfer as written in Yezierska’s mode, the transformation is equally illuminating. Yezierska might choose a single character—Ellen Thatcher, perhaps—as the emotional center. Instead of a rapidly shifting urban panorama, we would have a deeply subjective Bildungsroman set against the backdrop of the modern city.

Ellen’s struggles with class aspiration, sexual vulnerability, and artistic ambition would be conveyed through lyrical interior monologue. Her gaze would render the city not as a system of capital flows and mass media but as a field of desire, betrayal, and self-fashioning. Scenes that Dos Passos presents in a clipped, objective tone—a party, a theatrical audition, a romantic disappointment—might be expanded into psychologically rich episodes suffused with emotional metaphor.

Such a transformation would deepen the reader’s investment in Ellen’s interior world but distort the documentary ethos fundamental to Dos Passos’s critique of modernity. Yezierska’s rewriting would humanize the novel, but it might also blunt its political sharpness. Dos Passos critiques modern capitalism through fragmentation; the reader is meant to feel overwhelmed by the barrage of media and the impersonality of urban life. A Yezierska-style narrative, anchored in a single perspective, would impose coherence where Dos Passos wants disorientation.

Yet this rewriting also exposes the gender politics of Dos Passos’s work. His female characters often serve as symbolic types—ambitious actresses, exploited workers, sexualized figures—without the rich subjectivity Yezierska affords her protagonists. To let Ellen speak in Yezierska’s voice is to highlight the silencing that occurs in Dos Passos’s text. It is an act of recuperation, revealing how much female experience is left unspoken in documentary modernism.

The Space Between Form and Content

Placing the two writers in dialogue forces us to consider their shared historical moment. Both wrote in the wake of massive immigration, industrial expansion, urbanization, and cultural upheaval. Both sought to represent communities undergoing rapid transformation. Yet their aesthetic strategies diverge sharply because they seek to remedy different injustices.

Yezierska writes from the inside of the immigrant experience. Her formal commitment to emotional intensity arises from the belief that no sociological description can capture the psychic violence of assimilation, poverty, and patriarchy. Her novels enact what Marianne Hirsch calls “the immigrant’s restless hunger for voice” (Hirsch 1997, 81). The sentence itself becomes a home the immigrant may inhabit.

Dos Passos writes from the vantage point of political radicalism shaped by disillusionment with war, capitalism, and mass culture. His formal fragmentation arises from a desire to expose the ideological incoherence of American life. He does not grant his characters ownership of the narrative because he does not believe any individual consciousness can encompass the truth of a mechanized nation. For him, subjectivity is not a refuge but another casualty of capitalist modernity.

Their divergent forms thus encode divergent theories of agency. Yezierska’s insistence on voice presumes that the self can resist structural oppression by claiming narrative space. Dos Passos’s montage presumes the opposite: that the self is ground down by structures too vast to be apprehended individually.

The rewriting experiment probes this conflict. What happens when Yezierska’s faith in interiority meets Dos Passos’s skepticism of it? What happens when Dos Passos’s political systems are forced through the sieve of Yezierska’s emotional detail? The answers illuminate the political assumptions each writer bakes into form.

Gender, Labor, and the Politics of Narrative Authority

Gender plays a central role in the contrast between these two writers. Yezierska’s protagonists are overwhelmingly women navigating domestic, economic, and intimate constraints. Their emotional expressiveness critiques patriarchal structures that deny women intellectual, economic, and sexual autonomy. The family, the settlement house, the sweatshop, and the kitchen table become sites of struggle.

Dos Passos’s protagonists, though including women, are predominantly men shaped by the impersonality of public life: business, war, labor movements, politics. Their crises are often structural rather than interpersonal. Women in his novels frequently appear in marginal or symbolic roles, echoing and reinforcing modernist gender norms that prioritize male agency even within systems meant to critique capitalism.

Rewriting Dos Passos through Yezierska exposes this gap. A Yezierska-style Ellen Thatcher would critique not only capitalism but also the gendered structures of desire, economic dependency, and sexual exploitation left underexplored in Dos Passos’s work. The rewrite would not simply add emotional coloration; it would add a feminist analytic that Dos Passos’s montage resists.

Conversely, rewriting Yezierska through Dos Passos foregrounds the labor conditions that remain implicit in her deeply domestic narratives. Dos Passos’s documentary lens would expand the analytic field: the garment workers’ union, the municipal housing authorities, the political machines, and the philanthropists shaping immigrant life. His rewrite would push Yezierska’s narrative beyond the kitchen table and into the macroeconomic and political arenas that structure immigrant survival.

Thus each rewrite reveals what the original texts bracket.

Language, Ideology, and Hybridity

Language is central to Yezierska’s art. Her characters speak in a hybrid idiom that blends Yiddish syntax with English vocabulary. This linguistic hybridity symbolizes the cultural negotiation at the heart of the immigrant experience. To remove this voice, as a Dos Passos rewrite would, is to strip away the embodied history the language carries.

Dos Passos, by contrast, uses found language—newspapers, advertisements, patriotic songs—to emphasize how public discourse shapes consciousness. His characters rarely possess linguistic idiosyncrasy; their speech is flattened by the mass culture around them. A Yezierska-style rewrite would infuse linguistic particularity into the text, transforming mass culture into a more intimate, multicultural tapestry. The rewrite would highlight the many immigrant voices that Dos Passos’s America brushes past in its rush toward systemic critique.

Yet such a rewrite risks diluting the brutal impersonality of Dos Passos’s project. Yezierska’s linguistic richness humanizes, but it may also soften the jagged hardness of Dos Passos’s vision of modernity. The experiment shows that each linguistic strategy carries ideological implications: one insists on the cultural specificity of experience; the other exposes the homogenizing power of capitalist discourse.

The Ethics of Representation

Rewriting is not neutral. It forces us to confront ethical questions about who gets to represent whom, and how. Yezierska writes from within the community she depicts; Dos Passos often writes about communities from which he is somewhat removed. This difference shapes their authority.

A Dos Passos-style rewrite of Yezierska risks reproducing the voyeuristic gaze of sociological reformers who treated the immigrant ghetto as a field of data rather than a community of voices. A Yezierska-style rewrite of Dos Passos risks imposing emotional coherence on a text designed to resist such coherence, potentially misrepresenting his political intent.

Yet the experiment is valuable precisely because it surfaces these ethical tensions. It asks us to consider the relationship between politics and aesthetics, between voice and power, between systemic critique and intimate narrative.

What the Rewriting Experiment Ultimately Teaches Us

The most illuminating outcome of this hypothetical rewriting is the visibility it lends to the hidden assumptions of each writer’s form. Yezierska assumes that the self is the primary site of political meaning; Dos Passos assumes that the self is a casualty of larger forces. Yezierska grants her characters voice as an act of cultural recovery; Dos Passos fragments voice to reveal ideological manipulation.

Putting them into each other’s stylistic frameworks reveals that neither approach is neutral. Voice is political; fragmentation is political. Sentiment and documentary technique both carry ethical stakes.

The experiment also allows us to imagine hybrid forms. What might a novel look like that combines Yezierska’s passionate subjectivity with Dos Passos’s systemic critique? Perhaps it would resemble later feminist modernist works that merge intimate confession with political analysis. Perhaps it would anticipate postmodern, multicultural documentary fiction. In this sense, rewriting becomes speculative literary history.

In the end, the space between form and content is not a void but a site of ideological struggle. Rewriting Yezierska as Dos Passos and Dos Passos as Yezierska exposes the politics embedded in narrative choices, reminding us that the form of a story is often as politically charged as its content.
