AI ESSAY:
Distinctive Features of Indo-Pakistani English
Introduction

Indo-Pakistani English refers to the broad set of English varieties spoken in India and Pakistan, encompassing numerous regional, social and ethnolinguistic sub-varieties that share a core historical origin in British colonial contact but have developed unique phonological, lexical, semantic and pragmatic features (Kachru 1983; Rahman 1990). Although India and Pakistan diverged politically in 1947, English has remained deeply embedded in both societies—as a language of governance, education, upward mobility, science, technology and international communication. A substantial body of sociolinguistic, descriptive and applied linguistic research has explored the separate trajectories of Indian English and Pakistani English, but comparatively fewer studies treat them together as a related family of postcolonial Englishes with overlapping histories and structural features (Parasher 1991; Baumgardner 1998; Sailaja 2009; Mahboob 2014). Yet, many linguistic characteristics—such as stress patterns, retroflex consonants, lexical nativization and pragmatic norms—show extensive similarities that are more apparent when the two varieties are considered jointly.

This report presents a comprehensive account of distinctive features of Indo-Pakistani English, structured to facilitate an integrated linguistic analysis. It begins with historical and sociolinguistic background before moving to detailed discussion of phonology, phonetics, morphology, syntax, semantics, lexicon, discourse pragmatics, code-mixing, language attitudes and social indexicality. In addition, it examines how globalization, digital communication and diaspora dynamics contribute to ongoing change. Throughout, the report draws on established scholarship in World Englishes, sociolinguistics and descriptive grammar, while also synthesizing insights from research on multilingualism, language contact and identity.

Indo-Pakistani English is neither monolithic nor static. It is a constellation of dynamic varieties shaped by internal diversity—regional languages, caste and class stratification, religious affiliation, educational background, and exposure to transnational networks. At the same time, Indo-Pakistani English is unified by shared structural patterns traceable to common substrate influences from Indo-Aryan and Dravidian languages, the legacy of English language education under British colonial rule, and postcolonial sociolinguistic conditions that continue to shape local norms of use. The distinctive features discussed here illustrate how speakers negotiate linguistic identity, social mobility and communicative needs in multilingual contexts.

The core objective of this report is to elucidate key distinctive features across linguistic levels while explaining their origins, functions and variations. By examining Indo-Pakistani English not only as a set of deviations from inner-circle norms but as a systematic, legitimate and expanding set of varieties with their own norms, the report contributes to global understanding of postcolonial Englishes and their role in the evolving landscape of English worldwide. Ultimately, Indo-Pakistani English provides compelling evidence that English continues to diversify and localize, reflecting the social realities of its speakers.

Historical and Sociolinguistic Background

The historical development of English in South Asia began with the establishment of British trading posts in the seventeenth century, followed by administrative expansion and the institutionalization of English education in the nineteenth century. As noted by Kachru (1983), English became entrenched in the region not simply as a colonial imposition but as a language strategically adopted by local elites for social advancement. In both India and Pakistan, the role of English after independence remained significant, albeit with distinct political and ideological orientations.

In India, English functions as an associate official language and remains a key medium in higher education, law, science and administration, coexisting with Hindi and numerous regional languages (Sailaja 2009). In Pakistan, English retains official status and is widely used in government, military, law and elite education, often acquiring even stronger symbolic value as a marker of prestige and power (Rahman 1996; Mahboob 2014). Despite differences in language policy, both nations exhibit wide disparities in proficiency and attitudes influenced by class, region and schooling.

The sociolinguistic ecology of Indo-Pakistani English is characterized by pervasive multilingualism. Speakers typically command at least one regional language—such as Hindi, Urdu, Punjabi, Bengali, Gujarati, Tamil or Pashto—along with English. The result is extensive contact-induced change, code-mixing and nativization. These dynamics complicate attempts to define a singular norm but provide a rich environment for linguistic innovation.

Indo-Pakistani English is also shaped by educational systems. In India, English-medium schools often follow British or increasingly globalized norms, while large segments of the population acquire English as a second or third language in environments influenced by local languages (Annamalai 2004). In Pakistan, English-medium elite schools coexist with Urdu-medium government schools and madrasa systems, leading to stratified English varieties (Rahman 2002). These educational differences contribute to a continuum of proficiency and to divergent phonological and syntactic patterns.

Furthermore, the rise of digital communication and international migration has accelerated exposure to global Englishes. South Asian diasporas in the United Kingdom, North America and the Gulf contribute to feedback loops of linguistic influence. Thus, Indo-Pakistani English is continually evolving, formed by historical forces, social structures and global connectivity.

Phonological Features

Phonology is one of the most salient domains in which Indo-Pakistani English exhibits distinctive patterns. Many features stem from the influence of Indo-Aryan and Dravidian phonological systems, which differ substantially from British and American English. Other features reflect stable patterns of second-language acquisition under local conditions.

One of the most widely documented features is the use of retroflex consonants. Although English does not include retroflex stops natively, speakers of Indo-Pakistani English often use retroflex [ʈ] and [ɖ] in place of English dental and alveolar stops (Bhatia 1993). This substrate influence leads to distinctive pronunciations in words such as “tend,” “duty” or “water.” Retroflexion is common across India and Pakistan because Hindi, Urdu, Punjabi, Sindhi and other regional languages include retroflex phonemes. The use of retroflexion may also index local identity and has become a stabilized feature of many South Asian Englishes.

Another feature involves the treatment of dental fricatives. The sounds /θ/ and /ð/ in words like “think” or “this” pose articulatory challenges for many Indo-Pakistani English speakers because they are absent in major regional languages. Speakers often substitute /t/ or /d/ for these fricatives, producing pronunciations like “tink” for “think” or “dis” for “this.” While such substitutions also occur in other varieties of world Englishes, their occurrence in Indo-Pakistani English is patterned and widespread (Sailaja 2009).

Vowel length distinctions in Indo-Pakistani English also deviate from inner-circle norms. Many regional languages have a different system of vowel length and quality, influencing the English vowel inventory. For instance, the distinction between /iː/ and /ɪ/ or /uː/ and /ʊ/ is often reduced, leading to minimal pairs such as “sheep” and “ship” or “pool” and “pull” being less distinctly separated (Mahboob and Ahmar 2004). Stress placement may also shift, with speakers frequently using syllable-timed rather than stress-timed rhythm. Studies have noted that Indian English tends toward more even distribution of stress across syllables, partially due to transfer from Hindi and Dravidian rhythms (Pickering and Wiltshire 2000).

Consonant clusters present further challenges, especially word-initial clusters such as /ʃr/, /spl/ or /str/. Speakers may insert epenthetic vowels to simplify articulation, producing “istring” for “string” or “eschool” for “school.” Such epenthesis mirrors patterns in regional languages that avoid complex consonant clusters (D’Souza 1988).

Intonation patterns in Indo-Pakistani English also diverge from British or American norms. Research indicates a tendency toward falling intonation even in contexts where rising intonation might be expected, such as yes/no questions (Wiltshire and Harnsberger 2006). This can affect perceived politeness or directness when interacting with speakers of other varieties. Additionally, high pitch range, longer pauses and slower speech rate are sometimes observed, particularly among more formal or scripted registers.

Phonological variation within Indo-Pakistani English is considerable. Speakers from different regions exhibit distinct accents influenced by local languages. For example, South Indian speakers may retain features from Dravidian languages such as retroflex approximants or unique vowel qualities, while Punjabi speakers in both India and Pakistan may exhibit strong aspiration patterns. These internal variations contribute to the richness and diversity of Indo-Pakistani English phonology.

Morphological Features

Morphological features of Indo-Pakistani English are influenced by the structure of regional languages, especially the presence of agglutinative patterns in Dravidian languages and inflectional patterns in Indo-Aryan languages. Although English morphology is generally maintained, certain forms show localized adaptation.

Pluralization patterns in Indo-Pakistani English reflect both standard English rules and extensions based on local usage. For instance, uncountable nouns such as “furnitures,” “luggages” or “informations” may be pluralized (Kachru 1986). This pattern can be attributed partly to the structure of local languages, in which countability distinctions differ, and partly to hypercorrection or analogy with other countable English nouns. In everyday communication, such pluralization is highly common and often not stigmatized locally, though it may be marked in formal contexts.

Another distinctive morphological feature is the formation of hybrid compounds. Indo-Pakistani English frequently incorporates local morphemes into English words, resulting in forms like “timepass,” meaning an activity done simply to pass time (Parasher 1991). Other examples include “prepone,” widely used in India and Pakistan to mean advancing an appointment to an earlier time. Although not standard in British or American English, “prepone” follows productive morphological rules within English and has gained substantial currency in South Asian usage.

Verb morphology also shows localized tendencies. Speakers may extend the progressive aspect to stative verbs, producing forms such as “I am understanding” or “she is knowing,” influenced by aspectual constructions in Hindi, Urdu and other regional languages (Sailaja 2009). Similarly, habitual forms may be expressed using “used to” in contexts where inner-circle English prefers simple present or present habitual markers.

Compounding is particularly productive in Indo-Pakistani English due to parallel compounding practices in South Asian languages. Expressions like “wheat flour,” “godown keeper,” “hotel owner uncle” or “cousin brother” illustrate semantic and pragmatic distinctions encoded through compounding. While some of these compounds appear redundant from the perspective of British or American norms, they reflect distinctions meaningful in South Asian kinship systems and social organization (Emeneau 1956).

Reduplication, a widespread morphological process in Indo-Aryan and Dravidian languages, occasionally transfers to English, especially in informal speech. Examples include “small-small things” or “slow-slow,” used for emphasis rather than strict duplication (Abbi 1992). While reduplication in English is limited, its presence in Indo-Pakistani English reflects substrate influence and stylistic creativity.

Syntactic Features

Syntactic features of Indo-Pakistani English have received extensive scholarly attention, revealing stable patterns distinct from standard inner-circle Englishes. These include variations in word order, use of articles, prepositions, auxiliary verbs, tense-aspect constructions and relativization strategies.

One common feature is variable article usage. Speakers may omit articles in contexts where English requires them, as in “He went to market” or “She is teacher,” influenced by languages such as Hindi and Urdu that lack definite and indefinite article systems (Kachru 1983). Conversely, articles may be overused in contexts where they are not expected, producing forms like “the nature is beautiful” or “the democracy is important.” These patterns demonstrate the challenge of mapping English article distinctions onto local conceptual systems.

Preposition usage also shows localized patterns. South Asian languages often employ postpositions rather than prepositions, leading to divergences such as “discuss about,” “emphasize on,” “explain me the issue” or “enter into the bus.” Although some of these constructions are treated as errors in prescriptive contexts, they are widely used in Indo-Pakistani English and reflect systematic contact-induced change (Bhatia and Ritchie 2013).

Word order in Indo-Pakistani English is generally SVO, but certain constructions reflect substrate influence. For example, topic fronting or left-dislocation is common, as in “This problem, I am not understanding,” mirroring discourse-structuring patterns in Hindi and Urdu (Bhatt 2004). Additionally, the placement of adverbs may differ, with speakers producing sentences such as “I only told you” or “She fastly completed the work.”

Relative clause formation often uses resumptive pronouns, as in “This is the person who I met him yesterday.” This parallels relative clause structures in many South Asian languages, where resumptive pronouns are grammatically required. Although resumptive pronouns in English are generally restricted to informal registers, they appear with higher frequency in Indo-Pakistani English (Sailaja 2009).

Tense and aspect show further distinctiveness. The present perfect and simple past are often used interchangeably, leading to sentences like “I have seen him yesterday,” a construction influenced by the tense-aspect systems of local languages that mark pastness differently (D’Souza 1988). Similarly, habitual aspect may be expressed with auxiliary “do,” as in “He does go there often.”

Auxiliary verb usage can diverge from inner-circle norms, particularly in question formation and negation. Speakers may omit the auxiliary “do” in questions such as “What you want?” or “Why you came late?” This reflects parallels with Hindi and Urdu interrogative structures, which do not require a separate auxiliary. Similarly, negation may appear as “He no came” or “They are not having it,” blending English and local patterns.

Overall, these syntactic features underscore the systematic, rule-governed nature of Indo-Pakistani English. They illustrate how contact-induced change and multilingual competence shape syntactic structures that differ from standard British or American English but are internally coherent and widely intelligible within South Asia.

Semantic and Lexical Features

Lexical innovation is one of the most visible characteristics of Indo-Pakistani English. Many English words acquire new meanings or expanded semantic ranges, while novel lexical items emerge from borrowing, translation, compounding and semantic shift. These lexical features contribute to the distinctive identity of Indo-Pakistani English and reflect the social and cultural environment in which English is spoken.

Semantic extension is common, with English words taking culturally specific meanings. For example, “batchmate” refers to a fellow student in the same academic cohort, while “cousin-brother” or “cousin-sister” reflect distinctions in kinship terminology absent in inner-circle Englishes (Baumgardner 1998). The word “reminder” may refer to a small gift or token, while “eve-teasing” denotes sexual harassment of women in public spaces. These extensions demonstrate how English adapts to local sociocultural needs.

Lexical borrowing from Hindi, Urdu and other regional languages enriches Indo-Pakistani English. Words like “bazaar,” “pukka,” “veranda,” “bungalow,” “crore,” “lakh,” “hartal,” “gosht,” “chai” and “masala” have various levels of integration. While some of these are known globally, others are used primarily within South Asia. Borrowings fulfill referential and expressive functions, especially for culturally specific items, practices or concepts (Kachru 1983).

Hybrid forms emerge through blending English and South Asian elements. Examples include “timepass,” “setting” (meaning influence or connections), “airdash” (to fly somewhere urgently) and “out of station” (meaning out of town). These compounds and blends demonstrate productive lexical creativity and the influence of substrate languages’ morphological patterns.

Code-mixing between English and regional languages is pervasive in everyday conversation, media, advertising and digital communication. Speakers may insert English nouns into Hindi or Urdu sentences or vice versa, creating mixed forms like “scene kya hai,” “He is very kanjoos” or “Mujhe confirm karna hai.” This fluid mixing reflects bilingual competence, stylistic choice and indexical identity work (Bhatia and Ritchie 2013).

Another lexical feature is the use of politeness markers and honorifics borrowed from regional languages, such as “ji” or “sahib,” which are sometimes attached to English names or nouns to convey respect. Terms of address such as “uncle,” “aunty,” “sir” or “madam” are extended beyond family or formal service contexts, reflecting South Asian norms of courtesy and hierarchical relations.

Lexical variation across regions is significant. Indian English has distinct lexical items shaped by Hindi and Dravidian languages, while Pakistani English incorporates Urdu, Punjabi or Pashto vocabulary. Yet many features remain shared, especially in educated registers and written English across South Asia.

Overall, the lexicon of Indo-Pakistani English reflects a dynamic interplay of borrowing, innovation, semantic expansion, cultural specificity and multilingual creativity.

Pragmatics and Discourse Features

Pragmatic norms in Indo-Pakistani English are deeply influenced by sociocultural expectations, politeness strategies, hierarchy, collectivism and discourse patterns from regional languages. These norms shape how speakers perform speech acts, express politeness, manage interpersonal relations and structure conversation.

A prominent pragmatic feature is the use of indirectness. Requests, refusals and suggestions are often phrased indirectly to maintain politeness and avoid confrontation. Expressions like “You may like to consider,” “It would be better if,” or “I will try” may function as indirect refusals or hedges, reflecting norms of deference and face maintenance common in South Asian cultures (Sifianou 1992; Kachru 1992).

Address forms reflect hierarchy and respect. Titles such as “sir,” “madam,” “uncle,” “aunty,” “doctor saab” or “professor sahib” are used more frequently than in Western varieties of English. The extended use of kinship terms for older strangers, shopkeepers or acquaintances conveys politeness and relational closeness.

Discourse markers in Indo-Pakistani English differ from those in British or American English. Words like “actually,” “basically,” “only,” “itself” and “also” may serve as pragmatic markers rather than strict semantic elements. For example, “I was just saying only” or “He came yesterday itself” illustrate the pragmatic extension of these markers, reflecting influence from Hindi and other languages.

Conversational patterns often involve longer turns, overlapping speech and expressive intonation. Narratives may incorporate elaborate context-setting, moral commentary and evaluative statements, consistent with South Asian storytelling traditions (Bhatia and Ritchie 2013). Silence and pauses may also function differently, with longer reflective pauses seen as thoughtful rather than awkward.

Politeness strategies tend to emphasize solidarity and positive face. Compliments may be used more frequently, and self-deprecation is a common strategy to appear humble. Direct disagreement may be avoided, replaced by softened forms like “Yes, but…” or “I agree, however…”

Apology and gratitude expressions exhibit cultural differentiation. “Sorry” may be overextended to contexts of sympathy, and “thank you” may be less commonly used among close relations, reflecting sociocultural norms where gratitude is often implicit rather than verbally marked (Sailaja 2009).

These pragmatic features highlight how Indo-Pakistani English incorporates cultural values into communicative practices and creates meaning through culturally embedded discourse norms.

Code-Switching and Code-Mixing

Code-switching between English and regional languages is a defining feature of Indo-Pakistani English communication. It occurs in spoken discourse, social media, film dialogue, advertising, education and workplace interactions. Code-mixing often reflects conceptual familiarity, affective expression, ease of processing and stylistic choice.

Speakers may switch languages to index identity, signal formality or informality, or perform social positioning. For example, mixing English with Hindi or Urdu may convey cosmopolitan identity, modernity or affiliation with urban youth culture. In professional contexts, English may be used for technical or academic terms, while regional languages handle interpersonal or affective aspects.

Structural patterns of code-mixing vary. Intrasentential mixing involves inserting English phrases into regional language syntax or vice versa. Intersentential switching occurs at clause boundaries. Tag switching involves adding English discourse markers or phrases to regional language sentences, such as “You know,” “Actually,” or “Right?”

The presence of code-switching demonstrates bilingual competence and linguistic fluidity rather than lack of proficiency. It also contributes to the evolution of Indo-Pakistani English by facilitating borrowing, calquing and syntactic transfer.

Language Attitudes and Identity

Attitudes toward Indo-Pakistani English are complex and often ambivalent. English is associated with education, upper-class identity, global mobility and socioeconomic opportunity. At the same time, locally nativized forms of English may be stigmatized in comparison to perceived standard British or American norms (Rahman 1996; Sailaja 2009).

In India and Pakistan, English proficiency is a marker of class distinction. Speakers of elite English varieties often hold linguistic capital that grants access to better employment, social prestige and global networks. Conversely, speakers of nativized or regionalized English varieties may face discrimination in academic and professional settings.

However, there is increasing acceptance of Indian and Pakistani English norms in literature, media and digital communication. Indian English literature has gained international recognition, while Pakistani English literature is emerging as a distinct field (Baumgardner 1993). The growing visibility of South Asian Englishes contributes to shifting attitudes, legitimizing local norms and challenging linguistic hierarchies.

Language attitudes are also shaped by globalization and the rise of hybrid identities. Younger speakers increasingly embrace mixed registers, code-switching and localized slang. These practices reflect evolving identities that are simultaneously local, national and global.

Globalization, Media and Digital Communication

Digital communication has accelerated the evolution of Indo-Pakistani English. Social media platforms like WhatsApp, Instagram, Facebook and X facilitate rapid diffusion of lexical innovations, memes and hybrid linguistic forms. Hashtags, transliterated scripts and romanized Urdu or Hindi are ubiquitous, creating fluid boundaries between languages.

Media industries in India and Pakistan—Bollywood, Lollywood, advertising, television and digital content—promote specific linguistic styles that blend English with local languages. Movie dialogues often include iconic phrases that become part of everyday English usage, influencing youth sociolects.

Globalization introduces exposure to multiple Englishes. Many young South Asians interact online with speakers from the United States, the United Kingdom, Nigeria and the Philippines, contributing to hybridization and the emergence of cosmopolitan English registers. At the same time, local digital content reinforces indigenous linguistic norms.

Variation and Change within Indo-Pakistani English

Indo-Pakistani English is far from uniform. Variation reflects regional languages, socioeconomic status, educational medium, religion, gender and urban versus rural background. Indian English varieties also differ internally between Hindi-belt speakers, South Indian speakers and speakers of northeastern languages. Pakistani English varies among Urdu-dominant speakers, Punjabi speakers and speakers from Khyber Pakhtunkhwa or Balochistan.

Change is ongoing. Younger speakers adopt global slang, internet expressions and Americanized vocabulary. Some traditional features, such as rigid adherence to British spelling, are loosening due to American media influence. New phonological patterns are emerging due to exposure to global pop culture.

The interaction of local identity, global media and digital communication ensures that Indo-Pakistani English will continue to evolve in unpredictable yet systematic ways.

Conclusion

Indo-Pakistani English is a dynamic, multifaceted and culturally embedded set of English varieties shaped by historical forces, multilingual environments and contemporary global influences. Its distinctive phonological, morphological, syntactic, lexical and pragmatic features reflect systematic linguistic adaptation rather than random deviation from British or American norms. Indo-Pakistani English illustrates how English, as a global language, diversifies through contact with local languages and cultures, producing new norms that are deeply meaningful to speakers.

Far from being peripheral, Indo-Pakistani English occupies a central place in the study of world Englishes. It challenges monolithic conceptions of linguistic standardness and highlights the legitimacy of localized, nativized Englishes that serve the communicative needs of millions. Future research will continue to explore its internal variation, digital transformations and role in shaping global English.

TITLE: Age and Input: Which is More Important in Language Learning?
HUMAN ESSAY:
Age and Input: Which is More Important in Language Learning?

The acquisition of language is affected by many factors, a couple of which are the age of the learner and the consistency of the input received. Based on previous research, one would guess that language is learned best at a younger age and when the learner receives appropriate input on which to model his production. But what happens when one of these conditions and not the other is met? This paper will look at two case studies that differ in regard to these variables. One will examine the case of a child not exposed to language until she was well past the so-called Critical Period; the other will focus on a child whose only language input was highly inconsistent and unreliable. This double dissociation will allow the effects of these two variables to be contrasted, and one will be able to deduce which has a more profound impact on language acquisition.

Many linguists and psychologists have studied the Critical Period of language acquisition, in learning both a first language and any subsequent ones. As would be expected, it is hard to reach a consensus for the age at which this period ends. Lenneberg believes that language acquisition is precluded at puberty when the lateralization of cerebral function is complete (Curtiss 542). Krashen, meanwhile, states that the development of lateralization is complete well before puberty, so the critical period ends much sooner (Curtiss 542-3). Francis' (1999) study finds a disparity between those who acquired ASL between ages 3 and 7 and those who first learned it between ages 8 and 10 (431). His research supports the belief that age 6 or 7 represents a maturational milestone after which access to UG [Universal Grammar] begins to diminish (Francis 441).

The case of Genie, an isolated child who was not exposed to language until she was almost 14 years old (in 1970), provides much evidence supporting the Critical Period hypothesis, though she cannot confirm the end of this time span, being beyond it by anyone's estimate. Before she was sent to the hospital for rehabilitation, her only auditory input consisted of her father and older brother barking at her like dogs (Curtiss 529). Her father was intolerant of noise and punished her if she made any sound, not even keeping a television or radio in the house (Curtiss 529). It seemed that what she learned during isolation was to prevent sound production rather than produce sounds (Curtiss 532). Additionally, she was only fed infant foods, so she had little control over her mouth and jaw muscles (Curtiss 530). It took five months of hospitalization before she uttered her first words (Curtiss 534).

During observation and research, many have noticed a definite difference between Genie's acquisition of vocabulary (semantic information) and grammar (syntactic information). Genie could learn new words rapidly and add them to her long-term memory for later retrieval (Curtiss 540). Her first words consisted of names for colors and the numbers 1 through 5: much more complex concepts than those normally spoken immediately by first-language learners (Curtiss 535). She did not overgeneralize abstract ideas but extended them when appropriate (Curtiss 540). When she moved into the telegraphic stage, she already had a vocabulary of 200 words; normal first-language learners have only 50 available words at this point (Curtiss 535). Furthermore, she remained in this stage for four years, lengthening most of her sentences by adding additional strings of content words rather than syntactic content (Jones 264, 267).

The rapid acquisition of vocabulary contrasted sharply with a slow gaining of grammar. In fact, Jones (1995) states that the principle scientific conclusion drawn from the case is that Genie could not learn English morphology and syntax (261). He quotes opinions on both sides of this issue, many of which come from Curtiss, the principal researcher of Genie's linguistic habits. On one hand, Curtiss states, Genie's utterances…follow strict word order…There are exceptions to S-V-O order, but as with data on normal children…such order reversals are rare (Jones 275). On the other, in a later paper she asserts, Soon after normal children begin using structures…deleted elements decrease in number, and more and more of the basic constituents of the sentence appear on the surface. Not so with Genie. Throughout the period of observation, Genie has continued to delete subjects, verbs, objects, whether redundant or recoverable (Jones 276). By all accounts, Genie never came close to mastering the grammar of spoken English.

Still, Jones believes that Genie was capable of understanding more than she produced, as well as producing longer and more complex strings than she used (263, 266). Indeed, Curtiss believed that she could never discover Genie's true potential: Most of Genie's rules are optional; sometimes they apply, sometimes they do not. This variability in rule application, coupled with the preponderance of reduction and deletion, produces a surface syntax that often masks the underlying grammar (Jones 276). In any case, her total progress and potential for linguistic development remains unknown. Genie has had no contact with researchers since 1978, when her mother placed her in a group home (Jones 278).

Children born deaf face an isolation similar to abused or feral children. Less than 10% of the deaf community is made up of native signers, that is, children of deaf parents who were exposed to sign language (in this case ASL) from birth (Singleton 376). Most deaf children are born to hearing parents who encourage their children to speak, which is nearly impossible. Because of this, many deaf children are not exposed to ASL until they enter school, at which point they are nearing the (commonly-accepted) end of the Critical Period, and they will probably never attain a native-like language ability (Francis 431).

Conversely, some deaf children are exposed to sign language from birth, but often this happens in less than ideal circumstances. Many hearing parents learn some sign language to teach to their deaf children, but in this case they are learning along with the child, providing a very small amount of input. Similarly, some deaf parents of deaf children are not native signers themselves and thus do not have high proficiency in the language. Such is the case of Simon. His parents received their first exposure to ASL as teenagers (ages 15 and 16) and, despite having used the language for 20 years, have never mastered the morphology (Singleton 377). The inconsistent input they have provided to Simon was his only exposure to ASL until he entered school, and even then he was taught in a modified sign system based on English (Singleton 381-2).

Singleton (2004) compared Simon's verb morphology, a particularly complicated part of ASL, to that of children with native-ASL parents in order to test if this inconsistent and error-filled input negatively impacted Simon's signing performance (382). She discovered that, on his motion and location scores (some aspects of the morphology), Simon falls well within the range of competence for children of native signers (Singleton 388). Furthermore, in these areas, he exceeds his parents' accuracy by almost 20% in each category (Singleton 388). On the other hand, his handshape accuracy is lower than children of native signers, though it is still better than that of his parents, who have especially low proficiency in this area (Singleton 388-9).

Simon's language acquisition almost seems impossible to believe: how can a child acquire a grammar that is closer to the target language than that which he used as a model? Singleton has attributed his success to a phenomenon called frequency boosting, wherein a child takes the most frequently-presented forms in his inconsistent input and uses them himself, in a consistent way (390). In this process, he learns information and then reshapes what he acquires, changing a probabilistic set of competing forms into a rule system (Singleton 401, 403). Frequency boosting bears some similarity to overregularization of morphology, except that it both overregularizes virtually every morpheme and is permanently modifying the language, whereas those using overregularization would later return to their input to make changes (Singleton 402).

Most of the time the option with the highest frequency turns out to be the correct form, leading a learner in a direction closer to the standard. However, when an incorrect form is used the most frequently, a child tends to adopt it; this leads to a diversion from the standard and the adoption of errors (Singleton 395). This logically explains Simon's trouble with handshapes: his parents use nonstandard forms, so he boosts their frequency (Singleton 395). At the same time, however, Simon is often correct on part of the (standard) handshape, suggesting that he is in the process of surpassing his input, even in this area (Singleton 397-8). This mixture of correct and incorrect parts implies that he is at a lower level of target language development than other children his age; he may be displaying a longer learning process for handshape because of the extremely degraded input (Singleton 398).

In a way, Genie and Simon had nearly opposite language-learning experiences. Simon received inconsistent input and created comprehensible output. Genie, in contrast, received grammatical input and was unable to create consistent output. The only thing that can explain the gross difference between these results is the age of acquisition. Though some observers believed that Genie was still acquiring language when she was cut off from research, others say that her language development stabilized at a level far short of native-like competence (Francis 428). Meanwhile Simon was still improving at age 7; in fact, some aspects of ASL continue to be acquired later even by normal learners (Singleton 399-400).

As is obvious from the studies presented here, age of acquisition plays a much larger role in the ultimate language result than does consistency or accuracy of input. Children's innate language-learning mechanisms are able to analyze even the most unreliable input and create rules out of it, forming a language that (usually at least) moves them closer to the target language, establishing a disparity between their own language and that of the input-providers. The unimportance of perfect input should remove fears that student learners will acquire each others' mistakes through interaction, providing even more incentive for communicative teaching methods. In addition, all the research on the Critical Period has encouraged language-teaching to begin at a younger age, since children have more access to UG and are better able to acquire syntax and morphology.

References
Curtiss, Susan, Victoria Fromkin, Stephen Krashen, David Rigler, and Marilyn Rigler. "The linguistic development of Genie." Language 50.3 (1974): 528-554.
Francis, Norbert. "Maturational constraints in language one and language two: A second look at the research on critical periods." Bilingual Research Journal 23.4 (1999): 423-449.
Jones, Peter E. "Contradictions and unanswered questions in the Genie case: A fresh look at the linguistic evidence." Language & Communication 15.3 (1995): 261-280.
Singleton, Jenny L., and Elissa L. Newport. "When learners surpass their models: The acquisition of American Sign Language from inconsistent input." Cognitive Psychology 49 (2004): 370-407.
AI ESSAY:
Age and Input: Which is More Important in Language Learning?

Introduction
The field of second language acquisition has long debated the relative influence of age and input on successful language learning. Scholars have examined the cognitive, social, and neurological factors that shape acquisition processes, often arriving at competing conclusions about whether the timing of exposure or the quality and quantity of that exposure plays the more decisive role. These discussions frequently intersect with broader questions regarding critical period effects, neuroplasticity, language environments, and the adaptability of adult learners. Although age and input are closely intertwined variables, it is possible to analyze their respective contributions in order to understand how individuals across the lifespan acquire new languages. This report explores current theoretical and empirical perspectives on the roles of age and input, assesses whether one factor can be considered more important than the other, and argues that while age affects certain aspects of language learning, input ultimately carries the greater practical weight in determining linguistic outcomes.

Age in Language Learning
Age has been a focal point in linguistic research, largely due to the hypothesis that younger learners benefit from heightened neuroplasticity. According to the critical period hypothesis, a biologically determined window exists during which the brain is particularly receptive to language acquisition, especially in phonology and morphosyntax (Lenneberg, 1967). Young children, therefore, tend to acquire languages with native-like accents and morphosyntactic intuitions when exposed early enough. Studies of immigrant children, for instance, indicate that those who arrive before puberty often outperform older arrivals in measures of accent and grammaticality judgments (Johnson & Newport, 1989). This body of evidence points to age as a significant predictor of ultimate attainment, at least in some linguistic domains.

However, age does not operate uniformly across all areas of language learning. Lexical development, for example, does not appear to be as tightly constrained by maturation. Adults often learn vocabulary faster than children because they possess stronger metalinguistic awareness and more developed cognitive strategies for memorization, categorization, and inference (DeKeyser, 2012). Moreover, adults excel in explicit learning contexts, such as classroom environments that rely on rules and structured input. This suggests that age influences the pathway of learning more than it determines the possibility of high achievement.

Additionally, age interacts with social and affective factors. Children typically encounter lower pressure, more immersive environments, and more opportunities for naturalistic interaction, which can magnify the advantages associated with neurological plasticity. Adults, in contrast, may face anxiety, identity-related challenges, and limited exposure, factors that can hinder progress more than age alone (Dörnyei, 2005). These considerations complicate claims that age is the dominant force in language acquisition.

Cognitive and Neurological Perspectives on Age
Cognitive and neurological research has offered insights into why younger learners often display advantages in implicit language learning. Children are more adept at extracting patterns from rich naturalistic input without conscious awareness. Their procedural memory systems, which underlie the implicit acquisition of grammar and phonology, are highly active during early childhood (Ullman, 2001). Adults rely more heavily on declarative memory, which supports explicit knowledge of rules and vocabulary but does not always translate into naturalistic fluency.

Yet the relationship between neurological development and learning outcomes is not strictly deterministic. Neural plasticity does not disappear after childhood; rather, it diminishes gradually. Many adults achieve near-native proficiency, particularly when motivated and exposed to high-quality input over long durations. Neuroimaging studies indicate that adult learners can recruit alternative neural pathways, compensating for reduced plasticity in procedural systems (Birdsong, 2018). This suggests that while age shapes the neurological substrates of learning, it does not impose absolute limits.

Input in Language Learning
Input, defined as the linguistic data to which a learner is exposed, constitutes one of the most robust predictors of language development. Without sufficient input, acquisition cannot occur regardless of age. The quantity of exposure has been repeatedly linked to growth in vocabulary, morphological accuracy, phonological development, and syntactic complexity. For first language acquisition, children require a threshold level of input to trigger developmental processes; for second language acquisition, the quantity of input strongly correlates with proficiency outcomes (Hart & Risley, 1995; Unsworth, 2016).

Quality of input is equally important. Input that is rich, varied, and contextually meaningful supports deeper processing and facilitates the development of robust linguistic representations. Interactional input—language used in communicative exchanges rather than passive exposure—plays an especially important role because it provides opportunities for negotiation of meaning, feedback, and adaptation of language to the learner’s needs (Long, 1996). In contexts where learners receive high-quality input, age differences tend to diminish, suggesting that input can mitigate or even override age-related disadvantages.

Input frequency also affects linguistic entrenchment. Highly frequent structures are acquired earlier and more reliably than rare ones, regardless of age. Moreover, the distributional characteristics of input shape learners’ perceptions of grammatical patterns. Thus, exposure to diverse linguistic contexts—different speakers, genres, registers, and interactional settings—supports more flexible and context-sensitive knowledge. These patterns apply to both first and second language learners, highlighting the fundamental role of input across the lifespan.

Social and Environmental Dimensions of Input
Input does not exist in isolation from its social context. Children often benefit from supportive environments in which caregivers adjust their speech through strategies such as simplification, repetition, and emphasis, known collectively as child-directed speech. This type of input contains clearer phonological cues and heightened prosodic patterns, which accelerate acquisition (Snow, 1995). Adults rarely receive comparable scaffolding in everyday conversation, meaning their input is often less tailored to their learning needs.

However, adults can compensate by seeking enriched input through immersion, multimedia resources, formal instruction, or social interactions with native speakers. The increasing availability of language learning technologies, such as adaptive platforms and authentic digital media, allows adults to access diverse and abundant input that approaches naturalistic conditions. Therefore, while children may naturally receive more supportive input, adults have the capacity to curate their input environments strategically.

Motivation is another factor that amplifies the effects of input. Learners who are highly motivated tend to expose themselves to more input and engage actively with it. They seek out conversations, consume media, and practice in meaningful contexts. Consequently, the role of input often becomes intertwined with affective and social factors, and in many cases, these factors exert a stronger influence than age.

Comparing the Influence of Age and Input
When considering which variable—age or input—is more important, it is essential to distinguish between ultimate attainment and rate of learning. Young learners often achieve higher levels of ultimate attainment, especially in pronunciation and grammatical intuition, when exposed early and continuously. Adults, on the other hand, may initially learn faster, particularly in structured settings, because they utilize explicit learning strategies. Ultimately, however, both groups require substantial input to reach high proficiency.

Input arguably plays the more decisive role because it is the primary driver of linguistic development at any age. Age-related advantages cannot manifest without adequate exposure, whereas sustained and rich input can lead adult learners to high proficiency levels despite cognitive and neurological constraints. For example, research on heritage speakers demonstrates that children exposed to consistent input in home environments can maintain high proficiency even when formal instruction is minimal. Conversely, adults receiving intensive immersion experience, such as extended residence abroad combined with social integration, often exhibit remarkable gains that far exceed those predicted by age alone (Muñoz, 2014).

Furthermore, studies comparing learners with varying amounts of input—including bilingual children with different exposure percentages and adult learners in intensive versus low-exposure contexts—reveal that input quantity and quality are consistently stronger predictors of proficiency than age of onset. While younger age may facilitate certain processes, insufficient input can neutralize early advantages. Children who immigrate early but receive limited exposure, for example, may struggle to reach native-like proficiency, demonstrating that age alone is insufficient to guarantee high outcomes.

Interdependence of Age and Input
Despite the evidence favoring input, age and input are not fully separable variables. Younger learners often inhabit environments that naturally provide abundant, supportive input. Adults typically encounter more constrained contexts and may juggle work or family responsibilities that limit exposure. Thus, part of the perceived age advantage stems from differential input rather than biological maturation alone.

An integrated perspective acknowledges that age shapes how input is processed. Children may extract phonological and grammatical patterns more automatically, while adults may rely on explicit instruction and analysis. Nevertheless, both groups depend on input to activate their respective learning mechanisms. If input were to be drastically restricted, both children and adults would struggle, but adults might struggle more because they depend on a combination of explicit and implicit systems that must be adequately supported by exposure.

Therefore, the interaction between age and input is complex: age influences sensitivity to certain kinds of input, whereas input provides the material from which linguistic knowledge is built.

Pedagogical Implications
Understanding the relative importance of age and input carries significant implications for language education. If input is the primary driver of learning, then educational systems should prioritize maximizing exposure, especially in immersive and communicative forms. Programs that provide frequent, meaningful interactions—such as content-based instruction or dual-language immersion—can help learners of all ages achieve better outcomes.

For adult learners, pedagogical strategies should focus on enhancing input quality, integrating authentic materials, promoting interaction, and fostering environments that simulate naturalistic exposure. Adults benefit from explicit explanations and structured practice, but these should complement, rather than replace, rich input.

Additionally, recognizing that adult learners can achieve high proficiency challenges common misconceptions about the futility of learning languages later in life. While adults may face certain disadvantages, especially in pronunciation, they also possess cognitive strengths and the ability to manage their own input sources strategically.

Conclusion
Age and input both play essential roles in language learning, but their contributions differ in scope and mechanism. Age influences cognitive and neurological processes that shape the manner in which learners acquire linguistic structures, with younger learners showing advantages in implicit learning and ultimate attainment. However, input stands as the indispensable foundation of acquisition across the lifespan. The quantity and quality of exposure exert powerful effects on development and can moderate, compensate for, or even override age-related differences. While age may predispose learners toward certain strengths and limitations, input determines the opportunities available for growth. Consequently, input is ultimately the more important factor in language learning because it drives learning outcomes and can shape proficiency trajectories regardless of age.

TITLE: Environmental Justice Movements in Southeast Asia and the United States: A Macro-comparison
HUMAN ESSAY:
Environmental Justice Movements in Southeast Asia and the United States: A Macro-comparison
Abstract: This paper takes a sweeping look at the current state of the environmental justice movement in the United States. Then, by comparing both problems, causes, and outcomes of the environmental justice movements in the developing countries of Southeast Asia, analyzes the current successes and failures of the movement, and determines that greater social linkages with NGOs and governmental policymaking institutions would likely help transition environmental justice issues to the forefront of social dialogue.

IntroductionThe environmental justice movement is not even half a century old, yet its foundations are just being built. Many communities are just becoming aware that they are victims of environmental racism, and are educating themselves about environmental hazards to which their families and communities may have already been exposed. Others, aware of their situation and powerless on their own to help themselves, are learning the ways to petition the government and fight against industry to give their families and themselves a more healthy future. Academics and researchers are opening up whole new realms of study in linking zoning, housing discrimination, and other factors to environmental racism and discrimination, and most major research can not even be completed as far back as desired, the field and data is so young. Therefore, one of the best ways to analyze the progress and shortcomings of the movement is to compare it to similar movements abroad.

Although not explicitly called the environmental justice movement, many regions of the world share similar large-scale movements involving environmental or ecological injustices based on discrimination. In particular developing countries, as opposed to the more advanced democratic Western Europe, share this burden of discriminatory environmental practices for two reasons. First, these countries have a continuing population and economic growth that puts pressure on industry and land. (Hirsch & Warren, 1998) Second, they tend to have great wealth disparity and/or society is often broken up by class, which can breed another dimension of discriminatory actions. (Guha & Martinez-Allier, 1997) Among the regions that feature many developing countries with environmental issues, Southeast Asia makes a good parallel because it is the fastest-growing area in the world, making it vulnerable to environmental meltdowns, it has substantial links to the West, mostly through colonialism, and there are many studies and data available to compare environmental justice trends with the United States. This paper will attempt to show that the problems of the environmental justice movement in the United States are less hazardous and extreme than in Southeast Asia. Additionally, there is more of an effort by government and industry to conform to acceptable discriminatory standards, but the social linkages and the potential to politically mobilize around an issue like environmental justice seems to be much stronger among the movements in Southeast Asia, which could be a potential benchmark for the environmental justice movements in the United States.

Background & Procedure
The environmental justice movement is still a relatively young phenomenon in the United States. Birthed from the civil rights movement of the sixties and seventies, the movement began in the protests of those community members in Warren County, NC. (Ringquist, 2003) The movement began really taking off with the emergence of greater environmental awareness, specifically with hazardous waste sites and pollution as they relate to quality of life standards, a linkage that did not emerge in the public eye until the Love Canal controversy in 1979. Considering the relative youth of the environmental justice movement in the United States, as well as the ingrained racial tensions and discrimination practices that exist in the US as opposed to many other countries, it may come as surprising to some that the environmental justice movement is not a social movement unique to the United States. Indeed, while environmental issues often toiled in ambiguity, and were completely ignored by the important leaders of the US Civil Rights movement, environmental injustices were already being addressed in Southeast Asia.

The Chipko movement, more colloquially known and lampooned as tree hugging, involved fighting loggers in India with direct action to protect their resources in the 1960's and 70's, but also relied on almost exclusive female leadership and lent credence to gender equality issues as well. (Shiva & Bandyopadhyay, 1986) This movement was copied both in India and elsewhere throughout the region. Also, in the mid 1970's, the student-led TEMCO movement in Thailand forced the Prime Minister to withdraw extremely favorable (and illegal) mining concessions in southern Thailand, providing another example of early grassroots environmental movements of the less powerful. (Hirsch & Lohmann, 1989) The best example, and earliest, of a cognitive grassroots environmental justice movement comes from the Saminists of Indonesia at the start of the 20th century. Unhappy with the Dutch's increasing policing of the woods, the Saminists' main belief was that the state had not created the wood, just like it had not created the wind, water and earth, and that they all belonged equally to everyone. (Peluso 1994) Therefore, they refused to speak to Dutch forest rangers, continued to take wood from the forests, and refused to pay taxes. The Saminists were eventually persecuted, their leaders arrested, and the movement had practically subsided by 1910, but the idea was planted.

In this macro-comparison, I will analyze many case studies within the environmental justice movements of Southeast Asia, and match them up with similar case studies in the United States. The region of Southeast Asia is vaguely defined, but for the crux of this paper it will be confined mostly to the countries of India, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand. These countries can be looked at as representative of environmental justice movements in developing countries at large, not just Southeast Asia. For the sake of organization, the paper will break the environmental justice movement into three divisions: the problems, or injustices present (i.e. illegal dumping poisoning groundwater); the causes, or the actors responsible for the injustice (e.g. industry, government); and the outcomes, both the actions being taken by these movements to address the problem and the results of their efforts (e.g. community organizations, public rallies). Through this framework, comparisons can be made between movements in the two regions, and help shine light on what the United States Environmental Justice movement has accomplished so far and in what arenas it can improve. The conclusion of the paper will reflect back on the comparison by examining the trends of the data from a different framework: the Taxonomy of Environmental Justice. (Kuehn, 2000)

Problems
Environmental problems that citizens in the United States face share one major similarity with those in Southeast Asia: both movements are almost always addressing a negative change to the status quo. On principle, this sounds rather elementary, but looking at a field like conservation or even an issue like education, policymakers and activists are both campaigning very strongly to maintain or improve their sector, even if nothing is yet going wrong. Due to the nature of those targeted in environmental justice problems, the poor, minorities, and less fortunate; it is not surprising that those looking to scrape by from week to week would not seek to address an issue like water contamination or industrial expansion until the problem is figuratively in their back yard. One such example is Buttonwillow, a small town in California that was fighting to close or at least stop the expansion of one of the largest toxic waste dumps in the US. In this case, citizens become wary of the plant after an abnormal and particularly devastating amount of birth defects were occurring among newborns in their small community. This, along with child illness rates far above the state average, caused community members to begin actively paying attention and attempting to take part in government decisions affecting the toxic waste site. (Cole & Foster, 2001) The toxic waste site had been around for a long time before this environmental movement started, but the drastic change in the well-being of the community quickly changed the interest of the people there.

Similarly the San Fernando community in the southern-most island of the Philippines had never objected to the heavy commercial logging that in decades, had taken 80% of the island's forests away, until their soil had eroded away and they had lost much of their arable land that supplied their only form of sustenance. (Broad 1994) After their discovery, the citizens united in full force to sit down in front of logging trucks passing through town and staging fasts to save the forest that received much publicity. This is not to say that the citizens in either community are insincere to their cause, it is more important to point out that almost all action is mitigated by a problem in the environmental justice sector.

One problem that tends to be very different between the cases in Southeast Asia as compared to cases in the United States is this idea of land use vs. land preservation. In Southeast Asia, continued population growth and fast depleting resources, including good farm land and forests, creates a problem that is centered on land use. Oftentimes many of the poor and disenfranchised are literally displaced by their government in favor of industry, or may lose the value or sustainability of their land and/or job in the event that a richer, more powerful actor took it instead. Using the Philippines once again as an example, the small community of Itogon had been mining gold as part of small-budget operation for decades. When a corporation moved in with a vast concession from the government to strip mine this very same area, the people of Itogon literally lost their livelihood, in addition to the additional health dangers that the encroachment of industry can cause. (Broad, 1994)

In the United States, most environmental justice issues involve an externality of a site or pollution source, not the actual land itself. In the case of Convent, Louisiana, residents grew especially resistant after studies indicated that the new chemical plant would contribute to the air pollution that was 93 times greater than the average air pollution for the state of Louisiana as a whole. (Kuehn 2000) As with most cases in the US, the people of Convent were not concerned with the actual land, they do not care about owning it or using it, but what it would be used for, or if it would be a use that is harmful to its children. In developing countries as a whole, the greater percentages of natural resources that are left in proportion to developed countries, and a greater percentage of poor citizens who live off these resources, make land use the biggest issue in their environmental governance.

The second way that US environmental justice problems often differ from those in Southeast Asia has to do with the nature of the problems themselves. As reflected by the aforementioned communities in the Philippines, many of the victims of environmental injustices in Southeast Asia are losing their land, their homes, or their occupation when they give way to government or industry. In the state of Gujarat in western India, construction of a new dam precluded 41,000 families being displaced, and this is not a rare occurrence, it is estimated India has displaced 33 million people in the last 50 years, due simply to damming. (Taneja & Thakkar, 2000) This is not to say the people of Gukarat did not protest or go down without a fight, but in India the process is fairly systematic and 41,000 families is not a significantly noticeable number.

The often disastrous and immediate consequences of environmental injustice in India are contrasted by the US cases. Like the citizens of Buttonwillow, residents of Barrio Logan experienced increased birth defects, cancer rates, and adult and childhood respiratory problems; which lead to their concern in the Port Authority's use of Methyl Bromide, among other hazardous waste-producing facilities located nearby. (Holtzman 1998) These types of situations that residents in Barrio Logan go through in comparison to the situation in developing countries are a double-edged sword. While it is understandable that the displaced people of Gujarat, India are in far worse and immediate shape than the people of Barrio Logan, the people of India are in a predicament that is easily connectable to the problem and therefore, are often publicly assisted by the World Bank, or any number of international NGOs that have an interest in the downtrodden people of developing countries. The people of Barrio Logan, in contrast, are never seen in the context of having been a victim, and in this case as well it is near impossible to prove that the methyl bromide is the direct cause of birth defects, or any other health problems. Thus, while there are health risks associated with the residents of Barrio Logan, they are often not immediate enough to garner attention or funding to fight against their situation. It might be this difference, this shaping of the context between a human rights violation and an environmental injustice, which accounts for increased funding international NGOs contribute to developing countries every year while continuing to ignore environmental justice issues in the US.

Causes
The all-important linkage between the causes of environmental justice issues both domestically and in developing countries is that industry and government often have shared interest in pursuing path of least resistance. In countries like India and Thailand, huge economic growth places pressure on the economy to keep up with population, and in turn encourages government concessions to industries, which can lead to unrestricted degradation of the environment. On the other hand, for US industries, staying domestic might not be the most cost-affordable choice, and staying in business might require cost-cutting that results in a lack of environmental safeguards. Similarly the US government will do what it can to retain industry, and that includes subsidies and tax riders to get a corporation off the ground. Market forces are the only realistic explanation for the consistent discrimination of minorities and the underclass, and industry everywhere will almost always follow the path of least resistance. (Cole & Foster, 2001) What makes the US link up with the developing world in this regard is that the country still has an exploitable group of people, whereas in many countries in Europe, until recently in any case, there would not be such a path of least resistance, so to speak, making it harder to take advantage of one group repeatedly.

The main difference in the causality of the environmental injustice encountered is that the US cases tend to be more unintentional, or at least seem more unintentional, in their discrimination than many of the cases in developing countries. This idea of unintentional institutional racism in the US has been documented extensively and meshes very well with the cases in the environmental justice movement. In unintentional institutional discrimination, intentional discrimination in a related sphere can carry over into another sphere to produce a discriminatory outcome. (Feagin & Feagin, 1986) In the case of the US, many discriminatory practices in housing and employment leave minority or poor households in neighborhoods with bad air and water pollution, even though it was not necessarily the intent of anyone to put these people in the way of pollution.

Cases in Southeast Asia, however, show government and industry officials to be much more direct in their discrimination of underprivileged communities. The Sarawak region of Malaysia has often been entangled in corruption, with government officials interacting heavily with logging companies, and passing out 320 timber licenses in the meantime, most likely for favors. Despite the fact that there are two indigenous tribes on this land, the Malaysian government has ignored or showed open hostility toward the people who are already on the land. (Gardner, 1995) The reasons for this behavior are numerous; the rural poor and indigenous tribes have even less political clout and access to the media or government than do the underprivileged in the US, with less money and more resources to monitor, enforcement of laws is often unorganized or nonexistent within government officials themselves, and with less government restrictions corporations can be more bold in their practices of coercion or intimidation.

Outcomes
There are two major parallels between the outcomes associated with environmental justice movements in Southeast Asia and those in the US. First, the spread of horizontal social constructs to create a movement. The spread of horizontal constructs, or social capital, is the idea that ideas from one area, and groups of people and political groups, can spread to other areas, and there is a tremendous amount of spreading through organizations in both the US and Southeast Asia. In the US, the Civil Rights movement of the 1960's and 70's created institutions that would become adaptable to environmental justice activism. The Commission of Racial Justice, originally a civil rights group that was part of the United Church of Christ, was instrumental in helping to compose the United Church of Christ survey on hazardous waste sites and minority living that started the research on the subject back in 1987. (Bernier 2005) Similarly, the Assembly of the Poor, a democratic and class-based institution in Thailand attempting to give the poor subsistence farmers a political voice, has transferred seamlessly into raising awareness of resources and social justice, what one member calls an environmental democracy movement. (Fahn 2003)

The expansion of smaller simple community movements into larger well-rounded and influential organizations responsible for massive social change is the second shared outcome between the US and Southeast Asia. The Chester Residents Concerned about Quality of Life (CRCQL) is the best example of this type of expanding organization, although there are others such as West Harlem Environmental Action (WE ACT). What started as a single-protest against a factory later led residents to pursue action about truck traffic, argue their case at the Supreme Court, and form a partnership with a local college. (Cole & Foster, 2001) Along the way, residents who had volunteered to start the organization saw it grow into a massive direct action group that is capable of tackling a handful of environmental justice issues. The Association for Social Change (SPS) in India follows a similar lifeline to the CRCQL. Originally formed by fishermen downstream from a factory to fight against the pollution of a river, SPS soon was active in many regions of the country working against the Pulpwoods Corporation to keep from eliminating all of the region's raw natural resources. (Guha & Martinez-Allier, 1997) What is impressive about both organizations and what follows an increasing trend as these grassroots organization get older and learn more about what is effective, is their ability to use a variety of channels to get their message across and attempt to dissuade industry from continuing with their plans. Both of those organizations used petitions, litigation, media attention, non-violent protests, and personal appeals to government officials in an effort to reach their goals, and both represent the ideal of what many small grassroots environmental justice organizations strive to be.

One outcome that is different between the US and developing countries is the focus of environmental justice issues as part of the spectrum on environmental issues as a whole. Because of the increasing percentage of the poor who are politically active in Southeast Asia, and because of the successful linking of this environmental democracy movement to the Green Party, the environmental justice movement is the mainstream environmental movement in the region. In the US, however, environmental justice issues still take a backseat to mainstream environmental issues like air and water pollution, wilderness conservation and other deep ecology issues. (Guha & Martinez-Allier, 1997) One reason for this could be the lack of the US environmental justice movement to really connect with a party. While it is true that the Democratic Party would be far more likely to side on that size of the issue, many members have of the movement feel little connection to any political party, and prefer to get things done through other pathways. In either case, the lack of focus on the US environmental justice movement by its own citizens and organizations is somewhat unsettling, especially considering how similar the development between Southeast Asia and the US are.

Conclusion
The environmental justice movement in the US has flourished in the last couple decades almost entirely on a grassroots level. A typical successful environmental justice case involves a community taking on industry and government officials and institutions in order to overturn or prevent discriminatory environment practices. These communities usually receive only minor help or resources from private law firms or academics, and must learn to fight against injustice from a variety of areas. Where communities are often unsuccessful, it is easy to point out that they often lack the power and resources necessary to win necessary legal battles with the industries, and sometimes the areas of government, that are often the cause of their outrage. By looking at the environmental justice mechanisms in institutions, communities, and organizations within Southeast Asia, lessons and possible improvements to the US model were illuminated.

In terms of distributive justice, the problems in Southeast Asia are generally more dangerous and immediate threats to the livelihood of the people involved. This is not to say that the US cases do not feature a tremendous amount of risk and possible death, but in many cases, communities are losing their ability to stay above the extreme poverty line, or the ability to even feed their families when they lose their land or resources on which to make a living. With the population growth and advancement in this global economy, often the rural poor in developing countries are the only ones that are left to make the sacrifices for sustainability, which is completely unfair. By continuing to eliminate practices of discrimination and racism, intentional or not, the mentality of the path of least resistance and the bottom line can be avoided, and extreme poverty will not become a major factor here in the United States.

When it comes to procedural and corrective justice, the environmental justice organizations in Southeast Asia need to work to establish more rights and awareness of their fight in fixing these issues. The bureaucracy in large developing countries like Indonesia or India is large and slow, and oftentimes people without power and money are simply swept under the rug in a form of unintentional discrimination that results in a lack of information and enforcement on environmental justice issues that matter, especially to the poor and those in rural areas. Raising awareness, most likely through grassroots efforts such as non-violent protests and petitions, may garner assistance from an NGO or shine the spotlight on the state government itself, which would then likely address the issue.

In the area of social justice, there are lessons that the US environmental justice movement could take from its peers in developing countries. The environmental justice movement has flourished in Southeast Asia due to its linkages with traditionally dissident and minority parties, women's rights, and rights of the impoverished and farmers. By linking together more on all fronts, including both the basis of civil rights and environmental and quality of life issues, the environmental justice movement can become more of a political force. The environmental justice movement in the US has always been, in a way, very exclusionary. It originally came into being as an extension of the civil rights movement, and it has long been thought of in this country in terms of race, not class. It is time to grow the social capital, link with NGOs and political parties, who will be more accepting of a diverse and mainstream angle at attacking issues, and in doing so provide acceptance and assimilation to interested parties of different races and classes. The more diverse the movement can become, the sooner it can become a nationwide issue, instead of the romanticized picture of local communities fighting the good fight, being victimized unbeknownst to the public.
